C:831
(8) The following standards apply only to utility grid wind energy
systems:
a. Visual impact. Utility grid wind energy system projects shall
use tubular towers and all utility grid wind energy systems in a
project shall be finished in a single, nonreflective matte
finished color. A project shall be constructed using wind energy
systems of similar design, size, operation, and appearance
throughout the project. No lettering, company insignia,
advertising, or graphics shall be on any part of the tower, hub,
or blades. Nacelles may have lettering that exhibits the
manufacturer's and/or owner's identification. The applicant
shall avoid state or federal scenic areas and significant visual
resources listed in the local unit of government's plan.
b. Avian and wildlife impact. Site plan and other documents and
drawings shall show mitigation measures to minimize potential
impacts on avian and wildlife.
c. Shadow flicker. Site plan and other documents and drawings
shall show mitigation measures to minimize potential impacts
from shadow flicker.
d. Decommissioning. A Zoning Board approved decommissioning
plan indicating the:
1. Anticipated life of the project;
2. Estimated decommissioning costs net of salvage value in
current dollars;
3. Method of ensuring that funds will be available for
decommissioning and restoration; and
4. Anticipated manner in which the project will be
decommissioned and the site restored.
e. Complaint resolution. A Zoning Board approved process to
resolve complaints from nearby residents concerning the
construction or operation of the project.
f. Electromagnetic interference. No utility grid wind energy
system shall be installed in any location where its proximity to
existing fixed broadcast, retransmission, or reception antennae
for radio, television, or wireless phone or other personal
communication systems would produce electromagnetic
interference with signal transmission or reception unless the
applicant provides a replacement signal to the affected party
that will restore reception to at least the level present before
operation of the wind energy system. No utility grid wind
energy system shall be installed in any location within the line
of sight of an existing microwave communications link where
Sec. 39-17 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-17
C:832
operation of the wind energy system is likely to produce
electromagnetic interference in the link's operation unless the
interference is insignificant.

(1) Unless otherwise designated for review by the Zoning Board of
Appeals, an application for approval of any use designated in this
Chapter 39 as a special land use, special use or special exception
(collectively referred to as a "special land use") shall be reviewed
by the Planning Commission because of its unique characteristics
that require special consideration in relation to the welfare of
adjacent properties and the community as a whole. The Planning
Commission shall review an application for a special land use based
on:
a. The criteria set forth in this section; and
b. The criteria set forth in other sections applicable to a specific
special land use.
(2) These standards are designed to allow development and
investment, but at the same time maintain adequate provision for
the protection of the health, safety, and general welfare of the
community.
(b) Procedures. Notice of hearings on an application for a special land use
and special uses shall be given as provided in Section 39-4.1.
(1) The notice shall indicate that a public hearing on the special land
use request may be requested by any property owner or the
occupant of any structure located within 300 feet of the property
being considered for a special land use, regardless of whether the
property or occupant is located in the zoning jurisdiction.
(2) At the initiative of the Planning Commission or upon the request of
the applicant, a real property owner whose real property is
assessed within 300 feet of the property, or the occupant of a
structure located within 300 feet of the property, the Planning
Commission shall conduct a public hearing before making a
decision on the request.
(3) All special land use review procedures shall concurrently follow the
requirements for a Planning Commission site plan review pursuant
to the requirements of Article II of this Chapter 39.
(c) General approval standards. The applicant shall establish compliance
with the following standards to obtain approval of a special land use
application, in addition to the criteria set forth in other sections
applicable to a specific special land use. The proposed special land use
and its location shall:
(1) Be designed, constructed, operated and maintained so as to be
harmonious and appropriate in appearance with the existing or
intended character of the general vicinity and not change the
essential character of the area in which it is proposed.

safeguards or requirements as necessary to protect the health,
safety and general welfare of the community, for the protection of
individual property rights, and for insuring that the intent and
objectives of this section will be observed.

requirements and specifications and any required condition from
the Planning Commission.

(a) Purpose. It is the policy of the City of Holland, pursuant to the Federal
Fair Housing Act and the Michigan Elliot Larsen Civil Rights Act
(hereafter "fair housing laws") to provide individuals with disabilities
reasonable accommodation in rules, practices and procedures to
111. Editor's Note: See also Ch. 14, Art. III, Fair Housing.
Sec. 39-17.3 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-17.4
C:840
ensure equal access to housing and to facilitate the development of
housing for individuals with disabilities. This section is intended to
provide a procedure for individuals with disabilities and developers
of housing for individuals with disabilities to seek relief from the
application of zoning regulations, practices and procedures to further
the City's compliance with fair housing laws and provide greater
opportunities for the development of critically needed housing for
individuals with disabilities.
(b) Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following terms shall have
the meanings ascribed to them:
ELIGIBLE PERSON — A person who is an individual with a disability,
his or her representative, or a developer or provider of housing for
individuals with disabilities.
INDIVIDUAL WITH A DISABILITY — Someone who has a physical or
mental impairment that limits one or more major life activities; anyone
who is regarded as having such impairment; or anyone with a record of
such impairment, but such term does not include current, illegal use of,
or addiction to, a controlled substance (as defined in 21 U.S.C. § 802).
PERSON — An individual, partnership, limited-liability company,
corporation or other entity.
REASONABLE ACCOMMODATION — Providing eligible persons with
flexibility in the application of zoning regulations, practices and
procedures, or even granting variances from certain requirements,
when it is necessary to eliminate barriers to equal housing
opportunities.
REQUEST FOR REASONABLE ACCOMMODATION — A request by
any individual with a disability, his or her representative, a developer
or provider of housing for individuals with disabilities, when the
application of a zoning regulation, policy, practice or procedure acts as
a barrier to fair housing opportunities.
(c) Notice of fair housing accommodations policy, assistance available.
(1) Notice of the availability of reasonable accommodation shall be
prominently displayed at public information counters in the
Community and Neighborhood Services Department, advising the
public of the availability of the procedure for eligible individuals.
Forms for requesting reasonable accommodation shall be available
to the public in the Community and Neighborhood Services
Department.
(2) The notice shall indicate that the Department of Community and
Neighborhood Services will provide an applicant with assistance in
filing a request for reasonable accommodation or an appeal from a
decision on such request so that the process is accessible.
(d) Requests for reasonable accommodation.

(1) The Zoning Board of Appeals shall have the jurisdiction and power
to grant a special exception from the non-use requirements of the
Zoning Ordinance where necessary to provide reasonable
accommodation to allow individuals with disabilities to have
reasonable access to housing in the City of Holland.
(2) A special exemption is not necessary for state-licensed adult foster
care homes to the extent that state law preempts local zoning and
may exist legally without the special exception.
(3) An eligible person may request a reasonable accommodation in
zoning regulations, practices and procedures.
(4) Requests for reasonable accommodation shall be made in writing,
filed in the Office of the City Clerk and provide the following
information:
a. Name and address of the individual(s) requesting reasonable
accommodation;
b. Name and address of the property owner(s) (if different);
c. Address and parcel number of the property for which
accommodation is requested;
d. Evidence that the request is for an individual with a disability
under fair housing laws;
e. Description of the requested accommodation and the
regulation(s) or procedure for which accommodation is sought;
f. Reason that the requested accommodation may be necessary
for the individual(s) with the disability to use and enjoy the
dwelling;
g. All alternative accommodations and other options that have
been considered by the applicant;
h. Evidence of whether the property is within 500 feet of another
property granted accommodations for use by five or more
unrelated persons under this section; and
i. The written consent of the property owner.
(5) Any information identified by an applicant as confidential shall be
retained in a manner so as to respect the privacy rights of the
applicant and shall not be made available for public inspection
except as may be required by the Michigan Freedom of Information
Act.
(6) A request for reasonable accommodation in regulations, practices
and procedures may be filed at any time that the accommodation
may be necessary to ensure equal access to housing. A reasonable
accommodation does not affect an individual's obligations to
Sec. 39-17.4 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-17.4
C:842
comply with other applicable regulations not at issue in the

(7) Requests for reasonable accommodation shall be reviewed by the

(8) Notice of the application and hearing shall be given in accordance

(e) Standards of review. The written decision by the Zoning Board of
Appeals shall be consistent with fair housing laws and based on some or
all of the following factors:
(1) Whether the housing, which is the subject of the request for
reasonable accommodation, will be used by an individual with
disabilities protected under fair housing laws;
(2) Whether the requested accommodation is necessary to make
housing available to an individual with disabilities under the fair
housing laws;
(3) Whether the requested accommodation would impose an undue
financial or administrative burden on the City;
(4) Whether the requested accommodation would require a
fundamental alteration in the nature of the City's zoning program;
(5) Whether there is an alternative accommodation which may provide
an equivalent level of benefit to the applicant;
(6) Whether the recovery residence is state licensed as a substance
use disorder facility;
(7) Whether the recovery residence is a certified member of an
established entity that conducts its own inspections and has its own
standards for the benefit of occupants, e.g., CARF International,
National Alliance for Recovery Residences (NARR) or any
equivalent entity having similar requirements for membership;
(8) Whether the property should be managed by a person living on site;
(9) Whether and how the requested accommodation will benefit the
people in the program; and
(10) Whether the property is within 500 feet of another property
granted accommodations for use by five or more unrelated persons
under this section.

reasonable accommodation within 45 days from the date a
complete application has been filed with the Clerk and may either

threatens life or property, either on the ground or in the air, when such
emergency has arisen as a result of the operation of any type of aircraft.
(c) This section shall not be deemed to prohibit or restrict the use of
aircraft, including landing and takeoff operations, involved in search
and rescue, medical or emergency evacuation, traffic control or similar
uses under direction of governmental law enforcement or military
agencies.
(d) No lot, or any portion thereof, shall be used, designed or constructed
for the purpose of the landing of aircraft, as a principal or accessory
use, in any zone district unless approved by the Zoning Board, as a
special exception, after a public hearing thereon and compliance with
the following criteria:
(1) Evidence by the applicant that the proposed use will not violate the
performance criteria set forth in Subsection (a) of Section 39-84;
(2) Evidence by the applicant that the approach and take-off areas
necessary for the operation of the aircraft comply with federal and
state statutes, including the regulations and administrative rulings
promulgated under said statutes, and that the proposed approach
and take-off areas will not impair the reasonable use and
occupancy of adjacent and adjoining property; and
(3) Evidence by the applicant that the landing site and the immediate
and adjacent area affected by the wind velocity created by
approach or take-off of aircraft will be developed and maintained
with an impervious surface or grass covering so as to prevent the
nuisance of dust or dirt to adjoining premises, and further evidence
that the landing site affords reasonable margins of safety to
persons through fencing, open visibility area or a combination
thereof.
The Zoning Board may attach conditions to the approval of a
special exception requiring the applicant to continue to comply
with the levels of performance represented to the Zoning Board by
the applicant in the written application or in representations given
to the Zoning Board during the hearing process.
(a) Designed to primarily serve the needs of a home, farm, or business
located on the same site as the on-site use wind energy system.
(b) Shall have a maximum power generation of 30 kW.
Sec. 39-18 CHARTER Sec. 39-18.1
C:845
(c) Property setback.
(1) For stand-alone wind energy systems, the distance between an onsite
use wind energy system and the owner's property lines shall be
equal to or greater than the height of the wind energy system tower
including the top of the blade in its vertical position.
(2) For wind energy systems mounted on a principal or accessory
structure, the distance between an on-site use wind energy system
and the owner's property lines shall be equal to or greater than the
height of the wind energy system tower including the top of the
blade in its vertical position as measured from where the system is
attached to the structure.
(3) The distance between an anemometer tower and the owner's
property lines shall be equal to the height of the tower.
(4) No part of the wind energy system structure, including guy wire
anchors, may extend closer than 10 feet to the owner's property
lines.
(d) Sound pressure level. On-site use wind energy systems shall not exceed
55 dB(A) at any property line. This sound pressure level may be
exceeded during short term events such as utility outages and/or severe
wind storms. If the ambient sound pressure level exceeds 55 dB(A), the
standard shall be ambient dB(A) plus five dB(A).
(e) Electromagnetic interference. No on-site wind energy system shall be
installed in any location where its proximity to existing fixed broadcast,
retransmission, or reception antennae for radio, television, or wireless
phone or other personal communication systems would produce
electromagnetic interference with signal transmission or reception
unless the applicant provides a replacement signal to the affected party
that will restore reception to at least the level present before operation
of the wind energy system. No on-site wind energy system shall be
installed in any location within the line of sight of an existing microwave
communications link where operation of the wind energy system is
likely to produce electromagnetic interference in the link's operation
unless the interference is insignificant.
(f) Construction codes, towers, and interconnection standards. On-site use
wind energy systems including towers shall comply with all applicable
state construction and electrical codes and local building permit
requirements. On-site use wind energy systems including towers shall
comply with Federal Aviation Administration requirements, the
Michigan Airport Zoning Act (Public Act 23 of 1950, MCLA § 259.431 et
seq.), the Michigan Tall Structures Act (Public Act 259 of 1959, MCLA
§ 259.481 et seq.), and local jurisdiction airport overlay zone
regulations. An interconnected on-site use wind energy system shall
comply with Michigan Public Service Commission and Federal Energy
Regulatory Commission standards. Off-grid systems are exempt from
this requirement.
Sec. 39-18.1 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-18.1
C:846
Sec. 39-19. Changes, amendments, etc.; fees. [Ord. No. 464,
§ 9-1.22; Ord. No. 559; Ord. No. 872; Ord. No. 940, 3-16-1988; Ord.
No. 1188, 2-19-1997; 3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727; 12-19-2018 by

Sec. 39-19.1. Medical use of marihuana. [Ord. No. 1564, 6-1-2011]
No property in any zone district shall be used for the medical use of
marihuana (as defined in Section 39-192.1 of the Holland City Code). Except
as provided in Section 39-192.1, the Zoning Board of Appeals may not grant
a variance from the requirements of this section.
(g) Safety. An on-site use wind energy system shall have automatic braking,
governing, or a feathering system to prevent uncontrolled rotation or
over speeding. All wind towers shall have lightning protection. If a
tower is supported by guy wires, the wires shall be clearly visible to a
height of at least six feet above the guy wire anchors. The minimum
vertical blade tip clearance from grade shall be 20 feet for a wind
energy system employing a horizontal axis rotor.
(a) Changes, amendments, supplements, site plan review or other similar
administrative action to be taken pursuant to this chapter or to the
Zoning Map shall comply with the procedural requirements of Section 4
of Act No. 207 of the Public Acts of 1921, as amended or revised to the
date of such change, amendment or supplement. Applications for
rezoning shall be filed with the City Clerk and shall be accompanied by
a filing fee. The fee shall be set forth in a resolution adopted by the City
Council.
(b) The applicant shall hold one public outreach workshop and submit a
public outreach workshop summary report at the time of Planning
Commission application submittal in accordance with the procedures
and requirements of the City of Holland's Development Guide. These
requirements will apply to the rezoning of property to any zone district,
except R-1 or R-2 Zone Districts, when the property is adjacent to a
residential zone district and/or residential use.
(c) The City Clerk shall refer such applications to the Planning Commission
of the City for a recommendation to the City Council as provided by Act
No. 207 of the Public Acts of 1921, as amended and the applicable rules
of the Planning Commission.

ARTICLE II
Site And Development Plan Review
Sec. 39-20. Intent. [Ord. No. 1504, 6-18-2008112]
The intent of this section is to require varying levels of site plan and
development plan review and approval for buildings, structures and uses
that have varying levels of impact on natural resources, traffic patterns, and
character of the community. The intent is to encourage a high degree of
quality development and redevelopment of properties, without undue delay
when the impact is minimal. The regulations are intended to promote:
Sec. 39-21. Site plan, review required. [Ord. No. 1504, 6-18-2008;
Ord. No. 1551, § 1, 10-20-2010; Ord. No. 1700]
All proposals for development or redevelopment of land in any zoning
district shall be subject to review at one of the following levels before a
building permit is issued:
(a) Growth of the City in a responsible manner which provides the citizens
thereof with a safe, healthy, and beneficial environment;
(b) Safe and convenient pedestrian, bicycle, and vehicle traffic movement,
both within a site and in relation to access streets, adjacent and nearby
properties, and adjacent sidewalk network;
(c) Harmonious relationships of buildings, structures and uses, both within
a site and with adjacent sites seeking to draw on the best
characteristics of surrounding properties;
(d) Conservation of natural amenities and resources;
(e) Minimizing any adverse effects of traffic, noise, dust, and other types of
pollution;
(f) Protection and enhancement of property values and thereby secure the
fiscal base for public services;
(g) Compliance with the policies and recommendations from a variety of
City departments as it relates to the deliverance of public services, such
as utilities, police, fire, transportation, and so forth; and
(h) Compliance with the provisions of this article and all other applicable
City, state and federal laws.
(a) Planning Commission review. This review is conducted by the Planning
Commission and is coordinated by the Community and Neighborhood
Services Department (the Department) with review assistance from the
112. Editor's Note: This ordinance amended Art. II in its entirety. Article II was originally

(a) Utility service. All buildings shall be served by public sanitary sewer
and water. The development shall not overburden the sanitary drains,
water, solid waste disposal or similar public facilities and utilities. All
electrical and wired services shall be installed underground. All utilities
shall be planned and installed per the City of Holland and the Holland
Board of Public Works requirements.
Sec. 39-24 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-25
C:860
(b) Drainage. The drainage of stormwater runoff shall be accomplished in
such a manner so as to not adversely affect neighboring upstream and
downstream properties or the public stormwater management system.
If practical, stormwater shall be removed from all impervious areas and
carried away in an underground or surface drainage system or allowed
to disseminate into the groundwater aquifer via leaching basins.
Temporary on-site detention of stormwater may be required to reduce
peak runoff flows and velocities. Permanent stormwater storage in the
form of retention ponds may be required when deemed necessary by
the City or county drain authority. The City or county drain authority
may also require off-site shared drainage facility improvements
between the owners of the properties where sending waters originate
and the owners of properties receiving the water. Surface water in all
paved areas shall be collected at intervals and/or shall be directed via
sheet flow, so that it will not obstruct the flow of vehicular or pedestrian
traffic, and will not create long-term standing water in the paved areas.
On-site drainage areas shall be indicated on the site or development
plan. The approving authority may specify any required fencing or
other screening devices, if a wet retention pond is planned which may
be deemed to constitute an attractive nuisance. The area of a
stormwater detention or retention pond will be used in the calculation
of density on a site, and shall be an integrated part of the required
landscaping, open space, and recreational provisions of the
development.
(c) Streets, drives, and traffic flow. The applicant shall show either
unobstructed frontage on a public street or shall construct a public
street or private street or drive to assure public access to the project
site. The approving authority, subject to the concurrence of City
Council, has the discretion to require the construction and dedication of
public streets in accordance with City street standards. All streets and
drives shall be so arranged to provide adequate access to all buildings
for emergency service vehicles. In an effort to provide safe and
adequate levels of service in regards to adjacent and on-site street
safety and service levels, the site or development plan approving
authority may require the following:
(1) Limitations on the number and size of curb cuts;
(2) Determination of the proper number of lanes and lane widths per
driveway based on the expected trip generations and peak turning
volumes of the proposed land use(s).
(3) Restrictions or prohibitions of certain left turns if corner clearance,
sight distance, or driving spacing is determined to be inadequate.
(4) Driveways and streets aligned with driveways and streets on the
opposite side of the street, when appropriate and reasonably
possible.
Sec. 39-25 CHARTER Sec. 39-25
C:861
(5) Adequate sight distance assured for all vehicles exiting from a
development. If certain movements cannot be made safely, then
they shall be prohibited, or joint access with adjoining property
shall be encouraged.
(6) Minimum driveway and street spacing standards may be required
based on the Institute of Traffic Engineers (ITE) or other
acceptable urban planning or engineering standards.
(7) Improvements on-site and for immediately adjacent streets,
including, but not limited to: deceleration and acceleration lane
provisions, center turn lanes, bypass lanes, curb radii
requirements, clear vision areas, driveway throat widths, and
driveway and street intersection slope requirements.
(8) The approving authority may limit or prohibit the use of cul-de-sac
streets.
(9) Sidewalks/bicycle paths. Sidewalks or bicycle paths shall be
required along the frontage of public and private streets where the
approving authority determines such sidewalks are appropriate
and where deemed necessary to assure one or more of the
following: public safety; continuity with existing or planned future
pedestrian and/or bicycle circulation; and consistency with
sidewalk programs or policies adopted by the Holland City Council.
Sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete six feet wide and shall
be constructed to City specifications unless an alternate is
specifically reviewed and approved by the City Engineer and the
approving authority. Waiver of sidewalks during site or
development plan review does not prevent the City from requiring
sidewalks at some future date and assessing property owners for
the cost thereof, as appropriate. Bicycle storage facilities may be
required, where appropriate.
(d) Lighting. Outdoor lighting shall comply with the following standards:
(1) All streets, sidewalks, parking lots, and other common areas or
facilities shall be sufficiently illuminated to ensure the security of
property and the safety of persons using such areas and facilities.
(2) Lighting within any property that unnecessarily illuminates any
other property and substantially interferes with the use and
enjoyment of such other property is prohibited.
(3) All outdoor lighting used to illuminate the general area of a specific
site shall be shielded to reduce glare and shall be so arranged as to
deflect light away from all adjacent residential districts and
adjacent residences.
(4) All outdoor lighting shall be parallel with the ground and confined
to the ground areas of lawns or parking lots.
Sec. 39-25 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-25
C:862
(5) Light fixtures shall be designed so that no light emitted above a
horizontal plane parallel to the ground.
(6) The lighting of outdoor parking lots shall comply with Subsection
39-53(b).
(7) All lighting used for the external illumination of buildings,
landscapes, and merchandise so as to feature said buildings,
landscapes and merchandise, shall be directed downward and
placed and shielded so as not to interfere with the vision of persons
on adjacent properties, streets, or highways. For buildings
determined by the Department or Planning Commission to have
special architectural merit or public significance warranting
special lighting, the Department or Commission may approve
lighting which is not directed downward.
(8) Exterior illumination of signs shall be directed or shaded
downward so as not to interfere with the vision of persons on
adjacent properties, streets and highways.
(9) Artificial light and fixtures shall be maintained in a manner so as
not to constitute a hazard or nuisance.
(10) Exterior lighting of nonresidential properties shall be diminished to
levels adequate only for security purposes during times of the night
when the business is closed.
(11) In applying the criteria and development standards for exterior
lighting, the reviewing authority may consider and apply the
recommendation guidelines promulgated by the illuminating
engineers society for "minimum recommendations of lighting
levels" as existing or subsequently amended and such
administrative rules as shall be adopted by the Planning
Commission establishing criteria and interpretation for exterior
lighting development, pursuant to Section 1-7 of this Code.
(e) Parking, loading and unloading.
(1) For any new construction or land use, the applicant shall provide
parking and loading/unloading areas which conform to Article IV,
Off-Street Parking and Loading, of the Zoning Ordinance. For any
expansion which requires site or development plan approval, the
applicant shall provide parking as required by the article, provided
however, that the approving authority may modify the
requirements based on the following factors:
a. The parking requirements in effect at the time of original
development and current requirements.
b. The anticipated demand for parking in light of the proposed
expansion.

c. The availability of alternate parking either as shared parking
or on street parking within a reasonable distance from the
subject property as outlined in Section 39-51.
d. General site organization and its orientation to surrounding
properties and land uses.
e. Relationship to surrounding streets and access drives.
f. Internal and external pedestrian and vehicular circulation.
g. Aesthetic characteristics of the site, building, and parking
area.
h. The extent to which changes otherwise required will result in
mitigating negative impacts of existing or proposed
development on surrounding properties.
i. The extent to which the cost of compliance with current
ordinance requirements is balanced by the benefits realized by

j. The reviewing authority shall not impose parking requirements
greater than those required for new construction under the
Zoning Ordinance.
(2) In addition to the above standards, the reviewing authority shall

inches (measured six inches above the ground) caliper, street shade

Sec. 39-26. Additional development standards for PUD Planned

[Ord. No. 1504, 6-18-2008; Ord. No. 1585, 5-16-2012]
trees in right-of-way locations between the sidewalks and curbline
along all public and private streets; species to be approved by the

(2) All building and parking lot perimeters planted with appropriate
shrubs, trees, perennials and/or annuals, which may include a
mixture of turf grass.
(3) For every parking lot developed as a principal or accessory use,
there shall be provided on lands, contiguous to such parking lot an
area or areas of open space, planted and landscaped with natural
vegetation, at a ratio of not less than one square foot of landscape
area for each 10 square feet of parking area. Where any parking lot
exceeds 200 feet in any dimension, it shall further be required that
at least 50% of the required landscaped open space be provided
within the parking lot as opposed to the perimeter of the lot, so as
to mitigate the adverse aesthetic impact of large masses of
uninterrupted blacktop or concrete. No parking lot shall be closer
than 10 feet to any street, property, or common line with a
residential district line. These 10 feet shall be planted and
landscaped with natural vegetation.
(4) When a commercial or industrial development is proposed adjacent
to residential properties, screening and buffering in the form of
vegetative plantings and/or fences or walls may be required to
minimize any negative impacts on the adjacent residential
properties due to light, noise, dust, and other potentially negative
impacts.
(5) All required landscaping, screening and buffer areas shall be
maintained by the applicant and successor owners and/or
occupants. Trees and other vegetation that die due to weather or
cultural practices such as, but not limited to, too much or too little
irrigation, or incorrect pruning methods shall be promptly replaced
with in kind vegetation.
(h) Environmental quality. Any project shall be so designed as to
reasonably protect residents of such project, and residents or
occupants of neighboring premises, with respect to the emission and
transmission of noise, smoke, dust, dirt, litter, odor, vibration, light
glare, traffic congestion, ease of routine and emergency services,
drainage, erosion, light and ventilation, surface and groundwater
quality, overcrowding of persons, sanitation, property values, general
appearance and character, and other similar considerations.
(a) Percentage of uses in the PUD or PRD. The applicant shall submit
calculations of the percentage of the total acreage and floor space of
Sec. 39-25 CHARTER Sec. 39-26
C:865
each use proposed for the project. The Planning Commission shall
determine if the percentage of uses is appropriate for the size of
the project, location of the PUD or PRD, compatible with surrounding
neighborhood development, established and future traffic patterns, and
market to be served by the PUD or PRD.
(b) Area and density. Since the PUD or PRD district may serve to promote
creative design in the redevelopment of the central City areas as well as
cohesive development of outlying areas, no minimum area and density
regulations are prescribed. It shall remain the responsibility of the
Planning Commission and the City Council to review the proposed
density in each particular instance and to establish a maximum density
in cooperation with the developer based on such factors as:
(1) The size and projected density of individual dwelling units;
(2) Occupancy characteristics and needs of the primary market to be
served by the project;
(3) Proximity and inclusion of parks, playgrounds, waterways or other
open space;
(4) Density of adjoining and nearby residential and other
developments;
(5) Degree of redevelopment, if any, necessary for implementing the
project;
(6) Pedestrian and traffic circulation patterns.
(c) Parking. Parking shall be in accordance with Article IV of this chapter
and calculated according to the uses of the project. These requirements
may be increased in a PUD or PRD by the Planning Commission if it is
determined that the project will need additional parking spaces on site
due to the twenty-four-hour usage of the spaces, inability to share
parking with surrounding entities, impracticality of walking any
distance to the facilities within the PUD or PRD, or other such demands
as stated by the Planning Commission. Parking requirements may be
reduced in a PUD or PRD by Planning Commission. Such reduction shall
be based upon a finding by the Planning Commission:
(1) That the applicant has provided sufficient evidence to indicate
parking will be available through sharing of spaces by different
uses;
(2) That the parking requirement is excessive for the type of use
proposed;
(3) That walk-in trade for commercial centers will reduce parking
demand, or similar factors.
Sec. 39-26 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-26
C:866
The Planning Commission may require that additional parking
area(s) be designated on the final site plan but not constructed
until such time that the City or the developer finds the demand for
parking exceeds the number of spaces that are initially provided.
At that time the developer shall construct the parking area within
four months of a written request by the Building Official or upon
issuance of a building permit from the Building Official.
(d) Streets. In addition to the requirements of Subsection 39-25(c), private
drives or courts may be allowed within a PUD or PRD district:
(1) When intended to serve only residents of a particular development;
(2) When deemed adequate for the provisions of routine and
emergency services; and
(3) When acknowledged by owners/developers to be excluded from all
maintenance services related to dedicated public streets within the
City. Adequate provisions must be made by the owner/developer to
maintain the streets.
(e) Building restrictions. In an effort to allow flexibility in a PUD and PRD,
building restrictions should be kept to a minimum, except that each of
the following standards shall be adhered to:
(1) Building setbacks and height shall be determined by the Planning
Commission according to the use of the buildings and character of
the neighborhood.
(2) All portions of the land not developed must be landscaped with
trees, shrubs and suitable live ground cover.
(3) Any portions of a commercial structure or parking area must be
screened from any abutting residential area by a wall or berm
measuring not less than four feet in height.
(4) No portion of the off-street parking shall be any closer than 25 feet
to any property line adjoining a street or sidewalk. The remaining
25 feet between the parking and property lines shall be landscaped
in accordance with Subsection (e)(2). The 25 feet may be reduced
by the Planning Commission if more intense screening is provided.
(f) Enclosures. All processing or storage of merchandise and materials in a
PUD district shall be conducted wholly within a completed enclosed
building. Business and service uses may be permitted without
enclosure upon approval by the Planning Commission where
appropriate.

Sec. 39-27. Additional requirements for site condominium projects.
[Ord. No. 1504, 6-18-2008]
Site condominiums are allowed in any district. This section shall apply
to any new site condominium project and any amendment to an existing
master deed including, without limitation, an amendment which creates
additional condominium units by an addition of land or the conversion
of areas to additional condominium units. In addition to the standards
contained in Sections 39-25 through 39-29, a development plan for a site
condominium project shall also comply with the following requirements:
(a) Each condominium unit shall contain an appurtenant limited common
element for the exclusive use of the condominium unit owner which
complies with the applicable zone district, in which the site
condominium project shall be located concerning lot area, minimum lot
width and frontage, and required front, side and rear yards, unless such
requirements are specifically waived by the Planning Commission in its
approval of the development plan. For purposes of determining
compliance with these provisions, the condominium unit and its
appurtenant limited common elements shall be considered the
equivalent of a lot.
(b) Each condominium unit shall be subject to all other applicable
requirements of the zone district in which the site condominium project
is located, including, but not limited to, use regulations, minimum floor
area, and the maximum building height, unless such requirements are
specifically waived by the Planning Commission in its approval of the
development plan.
(c) Each site condominium project, and the condominium units created
therein, shall be constructed in compliance with the standards
otherwise applicable to subdivision plats and lots created therein
pursuant to Chapter 33 of the Code. Said standards may be waived by
the City Council of the City of Holland by a variance granted pursuant
to Chapter 33 of the Code of the City of Holland.
(d) Each site condominium project and the condominium units created
therein, shall comply with all applicable provisions of Chapter 32
(Streets and sidewalks) and the standards otherwise applicable to the
site condominium project for development, unless such standards are
specifically waived by the City Council of the City of Holland pursuant
to a variance granted there under.
(e) Each site condominium project shall comply with the requirements
otherwise applicable to subdivision plats contained in Chapter 33 of the
Code concerning public improvements, which must be constructed by
the proprietor of the site condominium project, including financial
security requirements to complete construction, unless such
requirements are specifically waived by the City Council of the City of
Holland pursuant to a variance granted pursuant to Chapter 33.

Sec. 39-29. Additional requirements for development in the C-3
Central Business District. [Ord. No. 1504, 6-18-2008]
Development within the C-3 Central Business District is intended to support
pedestrian activity through both the diversity of permitted uses and through
the character of the building and street environment.
(f) The developer of an approved site condominium project shall be
required to execute and deliver to the City any dedicatory instruments,
easements, or other documents necessary to convey and dedicate the
roads and utilities for public use.
(a) Review criteria. In order to support the character, safety, and use of this
district, site plan or development plan approval within this zone district
shall satisfy the following criteria, as determined by review of the
Planning Commission:
(1) Street-level building facades.
a. Along street level elevations of and facing type "A" streets,
there shall be a minimum window area of 60% of the portion of
the street facade, as measured beginning at 18 inches above
the sidewalk to a height of 10 feet above the sidewalk. For
measurement purposes, this percentage of window area may
include sills, lintels, muntins, mullions, and window framing, as
well as entry doors. For corner properties, the minimum
percentage of window area shall be no less than 40% of the
wall area within the defined limits on the secondary streetfronting
facade. Application of this subsection may be
determined by the Planning Commission to be eligible for the
optional plan review process.
b. Window area similarly measured for frontages along
permanent public open space and facing off-street parking
areas shall comprise a minimum 25% of the portion of the
building facade in order to facilitate visibility and security to
that open space and parking area. Application of this
subsection may be determined by the Planning Commission to
be eligible for the optional plan review process.
c. The downtown is characterized by frequent and inviting
building entrances supporting the pedestrian vitality and
continuity of the commercial center. Entrances to commercial
buildings along type "A" streets shall occur at least every 60
Sec. 39-27 CHARTER Sec. 39-29
C:869
feet. The Planning Commission may increase this interval
where it determines that:
1. The site is in transitional areas where street level
commercial activity is not yet mature or supported by
surrounding development, provided accommodation is
made in the design and construction of the building not to
restrict future additional entrances when more
comprehensive development has occurred and pedestrian
activity along this street frontage has increased;
2. The proposed building use is significantly compromised by
entrances placed at this maximum spacing;
3. On corner buildings, entrances along more than one street

4. Grade changes along the subject building frontage
significantly impede such access.
Application of this subsection may be determined by the

d. Materials shall be selected for street level building facades
that are compatible with the existing character of nearby

contemporary materials and design elements. Materials
selected must be of high quality and durable.

make a facade any less conforming to those standards than the
existing condition.
(2) Upper story facade design. Portions of building facades above a
storefront along type "A" streets shall be reviewed to assure the
design of those new building facades is compatible with other
features of the building and with positive attributes of surrounding
properties. Factors to consider include, but may not be limited to,
the amount, scale, and proportion of window openings,
compatibility of exterior building materials, and the architectural
ornamentation and detailing. Application of this subsection may be
determined by the Planning Commission to be eligible for the

Therefore, this Subsection (b) establishes an alternative process by
which the Planning Commission may evaluate and approve a

Sec. 39-30. Modifications to approved site and development plans.
[Ord. No. 1504, 6-18-2008]
development project that does not meet certain standards of Section

(c) Review by Downtown Development Authority. Prior to final action by

(a) Intent. The intent of this section is to recognize that changing
conditions in our environment and economy may require deviations
from approved site and development plans. This section sets forth a
process to approve these modifications when they arise. These
modifications may be due to:
(1) Unforeseen utility or geological problems;
(2) Changes in market demand over a phased project or during the
period in which an approval is valid;
(3) Changes necessitated by refinements to plans during the
construction documentation process; or
(4) New technologies or design features that would improve a
development.
Potential modifications are categorized into three sections: minor,
moderate, and major.
(b) Minor changes include modifications in which there is no significant
deviation from the approved site or development plan and include the
following:
(1) Minor adjustment in the layout of streets, drives or utilities.
(2) Minor reconfiguration of an approved footprint area to include
increases or decreases in building footprint areas.
(3) Minor relocations of building footprint areas provided there would
be no additional encroachment into required perimeter yards.
(4) Adjustments to parking relating to such footprint changes or to
other minor modifications.
(5) Relocation or addition of walkways, provided the intent of
pedestrian circulation is not inhibited.
(6) Relocation of refuse stations.
Sec. 39-29 CHARTER Sec. 39-30
C:871
(7) Modifications to signage plans.
(8) Addition of recreation equipment not involving permanent
buildings.
All such proposed minor modifications shall be submitted to the
Community and Neighborhood Services Department which may
distribute the site or development plans to the Board of Public
Works, Police, Fire, Transportation Services, and Leisure and
Cultural Services Department personnel for review and comment
with respect to applicable ordinances and policies. The
Department with consultation from the Zoning Administrator has
the authority to approve such minor changes or to refer the
proposed modifications to the Planning Commission.
In the event the Department determines that the change to the
approved site or development plan meets the criteria set forth in
this section, an administrative summary prepared by Community
and Neighborhood Services Department staff shall be placed in
the project file stating the nature of the change proposed by
the owner, the reason for such change, and the approval by the
department. If the subject site or development plan to be modified
was originally approved by the Planning Commission, a summary
of the Community and Neighborhood Services Department
approval shall be filed for informational purposes with the
Planning Commission at its next regular meeting.
(c) Moderate changes include those modifications which deviate enough
from the site plan so that they should receive Planning Commission
review and approval, but do not require noticing of a public hearing.
They include:
(1) Changes include changes to the approved site plans or
development plans that result in the reduction of lots in residential
developments;
(2) All amendments to approved development plans in planned unit
development districts and planned residential development
districts that do not increase that density of uses; and
(3) Other modifications not listed in Subsection (b) that are
determined by Community and Neighborhood Services staff as not
having any negative impact on surrounding property.

(a) Any person aggrieved by a staff administrative review decision to grant
or deny approval of a site plan, or modify an approved site plan, may
appeal the decision to the Planning Commission. The appeal must be
filed within five days of the decision, and shall state the factual basis for
the appeal. An appeal shall stay action on the issuance of any permit
pursuant to an approved site plan. The Planning Commission shall hold
a public hearing according to the requirements of Section 39-4.1. After
such hearing, the Planning Commission shall affirm, reverse, or
otherwise modify the original staff administrative decision, stating its
finding and the reasons for its action. A written copy of such findings,
reasons and actions shall be given to the appellant.
(b) Any person aggrieved by a procedural decision of the Planning
Commission to grant or deny approval of a site plan, or modifications to
an approved site plan, may appeal the decision to the Zoning Board of
Appeals (ZBA). The application for ZBA review must be filed within 21
days of final Planning Commission action.
(a) When a site or development plan is approved, in accordance with the
procedures and standards of this Article II, that plan shall be the
controlling element for building on a property. All foundation, building,
and site work shall be consistent with the approved site or development
plan. A filed site or development plan, approved under the provisions of
this Article II, shall have the full force of the Zoning Ordinance. Upon
Sec. 39-30 CHARTER Sec. 39-32
C:873
approval, a site plan shall be deemed valid for the duration of the
development period, provided, that substantial construction of utilities,
streets or buildings has commenced within 18 months of the date of site
plan approval. Substantial construction shall include the installation
of one or more underground utility systems, the installation of streets
or the installation of one or more building foundations. When the
site includes the phased construction of streets, utilities or other
infrastructure, which may relate to adjoining property or the public
interest, assurances that a timely completion is achieved may be
required. The site plan and development plan approving authority may
require a performance guarantee in the form of posting a bond or
irrevocable letter of credit for an amount determined by site plan and
development plan approving authority to ensure the installation of the
specified public or other approved site improvements.
(b) Site improvements and the construction of buildings must continue to
proceed in a diligent manner, and the project must be pursued
according to the phasing component of the plan. If circumstances
dictate a change in the phasing plan, a change must be submitted to the
Community and Neighborhood Services Department prior to the
expiration of the eighteen-month validity period. If site improvements
have not commenced in accordance with the eighteen-month validity
period, the developer, prior to the original expiration date, may file a
petition with the Community and Neighborhood Services Department
to extend the validity period for an additional one-year period. The
Community and Neighborhood Services Department shall forward the
petition to the original plan approving authority, which may add up to a
one-year extension if it determines that valid unforeseen circumstances
disrupted the implementation of the plan and that the plan may be
expected to proceed during the requested extension period. In the
event a plan approval period expires, and no site improvements have
commenced, nor has the developer requested an extension period prior
to the expiration, the plan shall be deemed void and invalid. The land
areas affected by such plan shall from thereon not be developed except
upon the submission, review and approval of a subsequent plan in
accordance with original plan approval procedures.
(c) Violations of any approved site plan shall be grounds for the City to
order that building permits be withheld, revoked or suspended until the
violation is removed or adequate guarantee of such removal is provided
to the Department and Zoning Administrator, along with such other
remedies for violation as may be prescribed by the Charter and Code of
the City of Holland.
(d) Continued compliance. Where an installation, alteration, or condition
has been established for approval of a site or development plan, the
continued adherence to the same shall be required for the duration of
the use or activity on the site. Failure to provide maintenance, as may
be necessary to assure the ongoing compliance with the terms of

Sec. 39-33. through Sec. 39-34. (Reserved)
approval, shall be deemed a violation of this Article II and subject to

The nonconforming use of any structure may be changed to another
nonconforming use upon public hearing and findings of fact by the Zoning
Board that the proposed nonconforming use will not be more incompatible,
detrimental, or create additional nuisance factors than the previous
nonconforming uses. The Zoning Board shall consider the following for its
determination:
(a) The lawful use of any land or structure as such existed at the time of the
enactment of this chapter or amendments thereto may be continued,
although such use or structure does not conform with the provisions of
this chapter or amendments thereto.
(b) Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as authorizing or approving
the continuance of the use of a structure or premises in violation of
zoning regulations in effect January 9, 1991.
(c) It is the intent of this section to permit nonconforming uses to continue
until they are removed, but not to encourage their survival. Such
nonconforming uses and structures are declared by this section to be
incompatible with permitted uses in the districts involved. It is further
the intent of this section that nonconforming uses shall not be enlarged
upon, extended, nor be used as grounds for adding other structures or
uses prohibited elsewhere in the same district.
(d) Nonconforming structures, conforming in use, may be expanded if the
following provisions are met:
(1) Parking be in accordance with this ordinance for such structure;
(2) Expansion conforms to the present zone district specifications.
(e) Notwithstanding Subsection (c) of this Section 39-35, certain
nonconforming uses within the C-3 District may be enlarged or
extended when satisfying requirements of Section 39-128(c)(1).
(a) Evidence that proposed nonconforming use will not adversely effect or
decrease the valuation of neighboring property;
(b) Evidence that the proposed nonconforming use will not increase
density, congestion or general nuisance to neighboring property;
Sec. 39-35 CHARTER Sec. 39-36
C:877
Sec. 39-37. Reestablishment of nonconforming use. [Ord. No. 1014,
12-19-1990; Ord. No. 1188, 2-19-1997]
Whenever the nonconforming use or structure or land has been brought into
conformance, a nonconforming use, structure or land shall not thereafter
be reestablished. In addition, if structure or use is altered, remodeled or
modified so as to eliminate or remove any or all of its nonconforming
characteristics, then such nonconforming characteristics shall not be later
reestablished.
Sec. 39-38. Repairs, maintenance, moving and restoration. [Ord.
No. 1014, 12-19-1990; Ord. No. 1097, 10-6-1993; Ord. No. 1152,
9-6-1995; Ord. No. 1188, 2-19-1997]
(c) Evidence that the proposed, nonconforming use will not increase the
amount of radioactivity, vibration, noise, odor, heat or other adverse
factors listed in Section 39-84;
(d) Evidence that the proposed nonconforming use will not necessitate an
increase in off-street parking which would be detrimental to
neighboring property; or
(e) Such additional factors as determined by the Zoning Board relating to
the health, safety, and welfare of adjacent property which would be
adversely impacted.
(a) Nothing in this article shall be deemed to prevent the repair and
maintenance of a nonconforming use or structure such as may be
necessary to maintain it in safe, sound condition, nor to prevent repairs
to damage not exceeding 50% of assessed value.
(b) A nonconforming structure and/or a nonconforming use which is
damaged or destroyed by fire, flood, wind, other calamity or neglect and
deterioration by 50% or greater of assessed value, at the time of
destruction or request for a building permit may be restored if the
Zoning Board finds the following conditions are met:
(1) Restoration of the structure and/or use will not substantially extend
the probable duration of the nonconforming structure and/or use.
Restoration of the structure or use will be done with similar
building materials, structural layout and design, construction
methods, fixtures, and mechanical equipment, thereby limiting the
possibility that such restoration will substantially extend the
probable duration of the structure or use; and
(2) Circumstances are such that the land previously occupied by the
nonconforming structure and/or use cannot reasonably meet the
criteria of that zone district.
(c) A nonconforming structure shall not be moved in whole or in part to
another location unless such structure conforms to the requirements of
this article.

Sec. 39-42. Nonconforming structures conforming in use. [Ord. No.
1419, § 2, 7-20-2005]
(a) Nonconforming structures, conforming in use, may be expanded or
reoccupied if the following provisions are met:
(1) Parking be in accordance with this chapter for such structure.
Parking spaces legally existing at the time of the enactment of this
chapter or amendments thereto may be continued and counted
towards the minimum amount of parking spaces required;
(2) Expansion conforms to the present zone district specifications.
(b) In all zoning districts except the R and PRD residential districts,
nonconforming structures which are conforming in use may be
remodeled and reoccupied for other lawful conforming uses as
permitted by right without the need for any variance or special
exception review, as long as there are no structural expansions of the
building footprint, or all structural expansions conform to the current
zone district height and area requirements. If applicable, the
requirements for site plan review are still in effect.
(c) In all R and PRD residential districts, nonconforming structures which
are conforming in use may be remodeled and reoccupied for other
lawful conforming uses when approved as a special exception by the
Zoning Board of Appeals pursuant to Section 39-42(d).
(d) The Zoning Board of Appeals shall use the following standards when
evaluating special exception requests pursuant to this section:
(1) Expansions of the existing building footprint shall not be allowed,
unless all structural expansions conform to the current zone
district height and area requirements.
(2) The use and any proposed building expansions shall be in character
with and will not be of substantial detriment to adjacent properties.
(3) Parking shall be provided at the ratio required in the parking
schedule of this chapter and shall be adequately screened with a
fence or vegetative screening materials when deemed necessary by
the approving authority.
(4) All new construction and remodeling activities shall comply fully
with all other applicable City codes.
(5) Reasonable conditions may be attached on the approval of a special
exception under this section if deemed necessary to protect the
public health, safety and welfare.

ARTICLE IV
Off-Street Parking And Loading
Sec. 39-45. Nonresidential requirements. [Ord. No. 622; Ord. No.
1097, 10-6-1993; Ord. No. 1163, 3-27-1996; Ord. No. 1188,
2-19-1997; Ord. No. 1254, 8-4-1999; Ord. No. 1360, § 3, 3-19-2003;
Ord. No. 1419, § 3, 7-20-2005; 3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727]
(a) No building shall hereafter be erected or enlarged nor shall any
building or land use be changed to another use, unless provision shall
be made to provide off-street parking and loading areas in conformance
with the requirements herein specified. Parking spaces legally existing
at the time of the enactment of this chapter or amendments thereto may
be continued and counted towards the minimum amount of parking
spaces required. Any person desiring to establish a parking area shall
submit plans to the Building Official showing the location, size, shape,
design, lighting landscape, curb cuts, drainage and other features of
the parking area. If such plans comply with the provisions of this
article, the Building Official shall issue a permit to allow the use and
occupancy of such parking area upon the completed development of the
area. Any use or occupancy of parking areas without the approval of the
Building Official shall be in violation of this article.
(b) If the parking area was subject to site plan review by the Planning
Commission, the applicant shall submit evidence showing compliance
with all requirements imposed by the Planning Commission. If such
plans comply with the requirements approved by the Planning
Commission, the Building Official shall issue a permit to allow the use
and occupancy of the parking area upon the completed development of
the area.
(c) With respect to a building expansion which does not require site plan
approval, an applicant shall comply with all of the requirements of this
chapter or such lesser requirements approved under this subsection.
The applicant may apply to the Planning Commission for a special
exception determination of parking requirements. The Planning
Commission shall determine the parking requirements based on factors
set forth in Section 39-25(e). The determination shall not be final until
the Commission gives notice to those persons who would receive notice
of a site plan review, if one was required. If a written objection is filed
with the Community Services and Development Department's office
within 10 days after notice is mailed, the Planning Commission shall
conduct a public hearing and make a determination of the parking
requirements based on the factors cited above set forth in Section
39-25(e). The Development Department may refer an application under
this subsection to the Planning Commission for a parking determination
regardless of whether an objection has been filed.
Sec. 39-45 CHARTER Sec. 39-46
C:883
Sec. 39-46. Mixed occupancies. [Ord. No. 464, § 9-1.6; Ord. No. 622;
Ord. No. 1188, 2-19-1997]
In the case of mixed uses, the total requirements for off-street parking
area shall be the sum of the requirements of the various uses computed
separately. Collective provision for off-street parking areas for two or more
buildings or uses shall be permitted; provided that the total of such offstreet
parking spaces shall not be less than the sum of the requirements of
the various uses computed separately. Parking areas for churches, theaters
or other uses in which the primary parking demand occurs out of normal
retail operation hours may be jointly used where adequate arrangements
are made to insure that the space is available for each function.
Sec. 39-47. Uses not specified. [Ord. No. 622; Ord. No. 685; Ord.
No. 1188, 2-19-1997]
For uses not herein specified or for mixed or unusual uses for which the
minimum requirements herein established do not directly apply, parking
shall be provided at the ratio of one square foot of usable total parking area
for each square foot of floor area, exclusive of basement area used for utility
or storage purposes. For outdoor commercial activities or for any use where
floor area is an obviously inadequate measure of parking needs, parking
shall be provided at the ratio of one square foot of usable total parking area
for each square foot of land or water area used for such activity or use.

Sec. 39-50. Units of measurement. [Ord. No. 464, § 9-1.6; Ord. No.
622; Ord. No. 1188, 2-19-1997]
For the purposes of this article, "floor area" shall mean the gross floor
area of all floors of a building or an addition to an existing building, but
shall not include basement floor area when used for storage purposes only.
The number of "employees" shall be determined by the maximum number
of persons employed, both part and full time, including all supervisory,
office, maintenance, production and other personnel, during any one shift
or work period for any given week during the most recent calendar year. For
new uses, the number of employees shall be determined by projected peak
employment estimates provided by the developer.

Sec. 39-54. Parking lot requirements for residential zone districts.
[Ord. No. 464, § 9-1.6; Ord. No. 549; Ord. No. 622; Ord. No. 1188,
2-19-1997; Ord. No. 1283, § 1, 8-16-2000; Ord. No. 1292, 2-7-2001]
(a) Off-street parking areas shall be surfaced with an asphalt, concrete or
similar durable and dustless surface. Off-street parking areas shall be
graded and drained to dispose of all surface water in accordance with
standard specifications for such construction on file in the office of the
City Engineer. Off-street parking areas shall be subject to the approval
of the City Engineer to insure its adequacy in relation to traffic safety,
protection of the adjacent property, and lighting standards.
(b) The outdoor lighting of parking lots shall comply with the following
standards:
(1) All parking lot lighting shall be shielded to reduce glare and shall
be so arranged as to direct and deflect light away from all adjacent
residential districts and adjacent residences. Lighting shall be
directed towards and confined to the ground areas of parking lots.
(2) Outdoor lighting poles, standards, or wall mounting heights shall
meet the following requirements:
a. They shall not exceed the maximum height limitations of the
district in which they are located.
b. They shall not exceed 16 feet in height from the grade of the
parking lot adjacent to the base of each pole when located
within 200 feet of a residential zone district, or they shall not
exceed 20 feet in height when it is demonstrated by an
illumination plan prepared and certified by a licensed
electrician, architect, or similar design professional that the
illumination level will not exceed 0.5 footcandles at any
property line that abuts a residentially zoned property.
c. Recreational field lighting and public streetlighting are
exempted from this height limitation.
(c) Where off-street parking areas are established without setback from lot
lines, wheel chocks or other restraining devices shall be installed to
prevent the encroachment of any portion of parked vehicles into
adjoining properties or public areas abutting such parking areas.
(d) Where an area proposed for the development of an off-street parking
area contains mature trees, landscaping or other site amenities, effort
shall be made, insofar as practical, to preserve such amenities and
include them in the overall design of the parking area or facility.

Sec. 39-58. Residential driveways, parking spaces and driveway
approaches—all zones. [Ord. No. 1226, 10-7-1998; Ord. No. 1260,
8-18-1999; Ord. No. 1357, 2-5-2003; Ord. No. 1517, § 3, 9-3-2008]
(a) Permits.
(1) A person shall not establish or expand an asphalt, concrete, pavers,
permeable pavement, grass pavers or another similar durable
surfaced driveway or parking space without first obtaining a
permit.
(2) A permit application shall be submitted to the Building Official
showing the location, size, shape, design, and surface material of
the driveway or parking space and the name, address, telephone
number, and licensing information of the person performing the
work. If the application complies with this section, then the
Building Official shall issue a permit for the construction and use of
such driveway or parking space.
(3) A person shall not commence any work within the public right-ofway
without obtaining a permit from the Department of
transportation services.
(4) A driveway or parking space shall be made accessible to the public
street by an asphalt, concrete, pavers or similar durable surface
constructed driveway approach.
(b) Placement of driveways and parking spaces within 25 feet of street
rights-of-way. Neither a driveway nor a parking space shall be placed
directly between a residential structure and the street right-of-way, or
in the front corner on a corner lot, except for a driveway to a vehicle
entrance of a garage attached to the residential structure. Additional
driveway or parking area such as expanded driveway width, parking for
recreational vehicles and turnaround accommodations may be
constructed in residential yards only when located 25 feet or more from
a street right-of-way.
(c) Driveway and parking space dimensions. The Planning Commission, or
in the case of administrative review, the City staff, shall establish
appropriate driveway and parking space widths for residential
developments subject to site plan review. For residential developments
not subject to site plan review, the width of a driveway or parking space
shall not be limited, except as otherwise set forth in Subsection (b) of
this section.
Sec. 39-57 CHARTER Sec. 39-58
C:891
Sec. 39-59. Parking space determination by the Zoning Board of
Appeals. [Ord. No. 1357, 2-5-2003]
The Zoning Board of Appeals may grant a special exception to vary or
modify the number of parking spaces required per this chapter. The Board
shall consider applications for parking determinations based on the
applicant's special circumstances to alleviate the need for the number of
spaces required by this Article IV, Off-Street Parking and Loading. The
applicant shall need to demonstrate that such varying or modification will
not be detrimental to adjacent properties including properties situated
immediately across the street from the subject property. The Board shall not
have the authority to modify parking requirements imposed by the Planning
Commission during a site plan review process.
Sec. 39-60. Parking location determination by the Zoning Board of
Appeals. [Ord. No. 622; Ord. No. 1097, 10-6-1993; Ord. No. 1188,
2-19-1997; Ord. No. 1226, 10-7-1998; Ord. No. 1260, 8-18-1999;
Ord. No. 1270, 2-2-2000; Ord. No. 1357, 2-5-2003]
The Zoning Board of Appeals may grant a special exception for parking
between the residential structure and the street right-of-way if the applicant
demonstrates that such varying or modification will not be detrimental to
adjacent properties including properties situated immediately across the
street from the subject property, and the applicant demonstrates one of the
criteria in this section.
(d) Driveway approaches. The Planning Commission, or in the case of
administrative review, the City staff, shall determine the number of
driveway approaches for residential developments subject to site plan
review. For residential developments not subject to site plan review,
only one driveway approach per street front shall be permitted.
Exceptions to these requirements are as follows:
(1) An additional driveway approach is necessary to provide access to
parking serving multiple residential units on a single lot, or
cumulative paving of the front yard will not exceed 40% of the yard
area.
(2) If street frontage on any one street exceeds 140 feet for a single lot
or multiple lots under common ownership.
(a) That varying or modifying the driveway, parking space, or driveway
approach requirements is the only manner to permit reasonable use of
a residential lot or to provide two independently accessible parking
spaces for the residential lot, and where there is insufficient lot
dimension to the sides or rear of the residential structure to allow
passage of a vehicle to the side or rear of the lot and that there is no
alternative access to the side or rear of the lot via an alley or other
dedicated access or easement.

C:892
Sec. 39-61. Violations. [Added 10-7-2015 by Ord. No. 1659]
A person who violates Section 39-54 or 39-56 is responsible for a Class II
civil infraction and is subject to the civil fines set forth in the schedule of
fees and charges adopted in Section 2-118 of this Code or any other relief
that may be imposed by the court. Each act of violation and each day upon
which such violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation.
Sec. 39-62. Paving and parking on traditional residential properties
in the Central Neighborhood District overlay area. [Added 3-7-2018
by Ord. No. 1726; amended 2-6-2019 by Ord. No. 1762]
(b) That traffic conditions on the adjoining street warrant the varying or
modifying of the driveway, parking space, or driveway approach
requirements of this chapter in order to better address safety concerns.
Traffic conditions to be considered may include but not be limited to the
posted speed limit, adequate site distances at the driveway intersection
with the street, the traffic counts on the street both over a twenty-fourhour
period and during peak hour times, and whether on-street parking
is allowed on the adjoining street. Such request shall be granted only
where there is no less intrusive alternative for safely entering or
exiting.
(a) Purpose. The Central Neighborhood District (CND) is a defined overlay
area encompassing portions of the Education District (ED) and the
Traditional Residential Neighborhood District (R-TRN). The purposes of
these zoning districts as set forth in Sections 39-280 and 39-320 are
reaffirmed and incorporated in this section. The CND area contains
large areas of properties with traditional residential structures on small
lots and large areas owned and used by long-standing educational
institutions, which also include some traditional residential structures
on small lots. Most of the small residential lots owned and used by the
educational institutions benefit from a broader unified parking plan
utilized by the institutions. Residential lots within the CND area face
increasing pressure to develop in ways inconsistent with preserving the
aesthetic value of such residential properties and the residential
qualities of their neighborhoods. These pressures include the
development of large paved parking areas on traditional residential
properties that increase the noise and congestion from the number of
vehicles in the area, in addition to those vehicles that park on the street
during the day. This pressure detracts from the desirability of owneroccupied
residences and the stability of the neighborhood.
(b) Rear and side yard paving. For properties with traditional one- to fourfamily
unit residential structures in the Central Neighborhood District,
the amount of paved areas for vehicle access and parking located in
rear and side yard areas shall be generally consistent with that of
adjoining properties and neighboring properties on the same block.
Plans to provide paved areas in the Central Neighborhood District for
vehicles that are determined to be greater in area than the amounts of
Sec. 39-60 CHARTER Sec. 39-62
C:893
Sec. 39-63. through Sec. 39-64. (Reserved)
paved areas generally consistent with that of adjoining properties and
neighboring properties on the same block may be permitted:
(1) In one side yard only covering an area up to 75% of the side yard
area. For a side yard less than 14 feet in width, a minimum paved
area of 10 feet is allowed. Landscaping and screening in the form of
natural vegetation and/or fencing are required to buffer and soften
the view from neighboring properties when side yard paving
exceeds a width of 10 feet.
(2) For a corner lot, the maximum paving within the side yards is up to
50% of the yard area with paving set back a minimum of 10 feet
from the public sidewalk or street right-of-way. Landscaping and
screening in the form of natural vegetation and/or fencing are
required to buffer the view from neighboring properties.
Notwithstanding where adequate dimension exists, this shall not
prohibit a driveway with a minimum width of 10 feet entering from
the street.
(3) On up to 50% of the rear yard if landscaping and screening in the
form of natural vegetation and/or fencing are provided to buffer
and soften the view of the side and rear yard paved surfaces from
neighboring properties.
(4) The remainder of the rear yard shall be green space.
(c) Violations. A person who violates this Section 39-62 is responsible for a
Class II civil infraction and is subject to the civil fines set forth in the
schedule of fees and charges adopted in Section 2-118 of this Code or
any other relief that may be imposed by the court. Each act of violation
and each day upon which such violation occurs shall constitute a
separate violation. Violations are also deemed a nuisance per se.
