Sec. 39-69. Accessory uses of commercial and industrial yards.
[Ord. No. 1239, 3-24-1999]
The following accessory uses or encroachments shall not be deemed
inconsistent with the intent and purpose of maintaining open unoccupied
commercial and industrial yard spaces, and may be permitted in required
commercial and industrial yard areas. In no case, however, shall any
commercial or industrial yard area be used for any purpose or in any
manner which would adversely effect the reasonable enjoyment of adjoining
properties, or which would be likely to create or increase a nuisance.
(a) The following commercial and industrial accessory uses shall be
permitted:
(1) Arbors, trellises, yard ornaments, statuary, or flagpoles.
(2) Eaves or awnings projecting not more than three feet beyond the
face of a wall, but in no case closer than one foot to property line.
(3) Plantings, shrubs, landscaping and indigenous vegetation.
(4) Parking of passenger vehicles in approved parking areas and
surfaces.
(5) Pole mounted yard lights.
(6) Brick veneer or other new exterior wall surfacing to existing
buildings.
(7) Signs which are permitted by Article IX of this chapter.
(8) Bay windows and chimneys projecting not more than three feet
from the face of a wall and encroaching no closer than five feet to
any property line.
(9) Mailboxes installed or mounted in accordance with federal law.
(10) Fences and screening which comply with the following limitations:
a. In commercial districts, they shall not exceed six feet in height
in side and rear yards and four feet in height in front yards and
side yards adjoining a side street.
113. Editor's Note: The title of this Division 1 was amended 10-20-2010 by Ord. No. 1551.
Sec. 39-69 CHARTER Sec. 39-69
C:897
b. In industrial districts, they shall not exceed eight feet in height
in side and rear yards and four feet in height in front yards and
side yards adjoining a side street.
c. Fence gates shall not swing over a public sidewalk.
(11) Accessory recreational equipment, including picnic tables and
barbecues.
(12) Pad mounted air-conditioning, heating or ventilating equipment.
(13) Accessory buildings in commercial and industrial districts used for
the storage of lawn care and other equipment for the purpose of onsite
maintenance, with the following limitations:
a. Maximum size of 120 square feet.
b. No accessory building allowed in any required front yard area.
c. Maximum of one accessory building per lot pursuant to these
requirements.
d. If the accessory building is 60 feet or more from any front yard
property line, it is permitted two feet from a side or rear lot
line.
(14) Swimming pools as permitted by Section 39-195.
(15) Refuse storage facilities, in accordance with Chapter 27 of this
Code.
(16) Accessory uses not specifically itemized, but which are similar in
nature and scope to any of the foregoing uses, recognized as
appropriate and approved during the site plan review process.
(17) Strings of lights on private property. All lights shall be maintained
in good condition and shall not flash, blink, oscillate, have any
appearance of movement, create a nuisance or be hung in a way
which could be considered a sign. [Added 1-2-2019 by Ord. No.
1760]
(b) In addition to the foregoing, fences of unrestricted height, playground
equipment, shelters or pavilions, fountains, sculpture and similar
installations of a scale not commonly found in commercial and
industrial yards may be permitted in conjunction with permitted uses
and approved during the site plan review process.
(c) Notwithstanding the foregoing, no fence, hedge, vegetation,
obstruction, or other accessory use shall be permitted or maintained,
which materially impedes traffic visibility across a corner lot, or
otherwise obstructs required open spaces in a manner that constitutes
a hazard to the safe use of public streets and sidewalks as determined
by the Police Department.

The I-1 Industrial District is intended to meet the needs of established and
prospective industry within the industrial areas of the City other than an
I-2 Industrial District. In addition to manufacturing, fabrication, assembly
and similar operations, this district allows material storage and supply,
construction trades, automotive services and commercial uses, subject,
however, to the requirements and prohibitions set forth in this division. The

Sec. 39-71. Prohibited uses. [Ord. No. 464, § 9-1.8; Ord. 601; Ord.

1482, 10-3-2007; Ord. No. 1506, § 2, 6-18-2008]
Within any area of the City which is zoned as I-1 Industrial District, no
building, structure or premises shall be used and no building or structure
shall be constructed or altered which is intended or designed to be used in
whole or in part for any of the following uses:
(1) Manufacturing, development, fabrication, compounding, processing,
assembly or treatment of materials, substances or objects, except as
hereinafter qualified in Section 39-72.
(2) Offices, research, testing or development facilities.
(3) Freight terminals, storage or warehousing.
(4) Storage and distribution of steel, lumber, bricks, blocks and similar
construction materials.
(5) Public utility facilities, including manufacturing, treatment, storage and
service areas.
(6) Automotive and machinery sales and services.
(7) Construction trades and services.
(8) Wholesale and retail commercial sales and services, including
restaurant uses.
(9) Municipal administrative and municipal services.
(10) Indoor archery or firearm range but only if permitted as a special land
use pursuant to Sections 39-17.1 and 39-17.2.
(11) Accessory uses that are customarily incidental to any principal use
permitted.

specifically requests the Zoning Board of Appeals to consider such
additional land in the granting of a special exception. Any expansion
onto land not so considered by the Zoning Board of Appeals in the
granting of a special exception shall be subject to additional
proceedings before the Zoning Board of Appeals in accordance with the
requirements of this section.
(c) The applicant shall submit to the City Clerk a legal description of all
lands considered by the Zoning Board of Appeals in proceedings
pursuant to this section. In the event the Zoning Board of Appeals
approves the proposed use as a special exception the Clerk shall, at the
expense of the applicant, record a copy of the order of the Zoning Board
of Appeals in the office of the registrar of deeds of the county in which
such lands are located.

the peculiar operating characteristics of the proposed use. In
consideration of the granting of a special exception permit, no use shall
be approved which would be contrary to the following environmental
guidelines:
(1) Radioactivity. Any use of radioactive substances, isotopes or
products shall present no hazard to the health, safety or property of
others;
(2) Vibration. Every use shall avoid causing vibration of the land or air
to such an extent as to interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of
any present or prospective legally conforming use of adjoining or
nearby premises;
(3) Noise. Every use shall avoid the emission of noise of such pressure,
loudness, pitch or frequency of occurrence, or any combination
thereof, which would interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of
any present or prospective legally conforming use of adjoining or
nearby premises;
(4) Odor. Every use shall avoid the emission of odorous gases or matter
in such quantities as to be noxious, offensive or injurious beyond
the property line of the parcel devoted to such use, or any present
or prospective legally conforming use;
(5) Heat. Every use shall avoid the discharge or exhausting of heated
air or water in such quantities as to be detrimental to the
reasonable enjoyment of adjoining premises or to plant or animal
life downwind or downstream from such discharge;
(6) Nuisance. Every use that may likely be deleterious to, or have an
adverse effect on, other uses lawfully conducted within the

Sec. 39-80. Intent and permitted uses. [Ord. No. 625; Ord. No. 691;

The I-2 Industrial District is intended to provide areas in the City in which
industrial uses may be located in such a manner as to preserve and develop
land area in a manner consistent with an industrial park concept. It is
the purpose of the I-2 zone to require industrial development and uses in
areas classified as I-2, which will conform to requirements different from
those of the I-1 Industrial District and which will result in industrial park
developments. It is the specific purpose of the I-2 zone to provide for open
landscaped yards, for off-street parking and loading within the industrial
park and for the protection from those conditions which would not be
compatible with a concentration of industrial uses. The following uses are
permitted:
Sec. 39-81. Prohibited uses. [Ord. No. 625; Ord. No. 691; Ord. No.

building, structure or premises shall be used and no building or structure
shall be constructed or altered which is intended or designed to be used in
whole or in part for any of the following uses:

assembly or treatment of materials, substances or objects.
(b) Offices, research, testing or development facilities.

equipment, supplies, materials or products.
(e) Automotive repair services.

(a) As new dwellings or as conversions of existing dwelling buildings to

(a) Permit; application. Any person seeking to use property for any of the
types of uses specified in Section 39-82 as allowable in an I-2 Industrial
District, either as a principal use or as an accessory use, shall make
application therefore to the Zoning Board of Appeals. The Zoning Board
of Appeals shall proceed in accordance with applicable statutes and the
provisions of Article XII of this chapter, to hear such application. It shall
be the duty of the applicant for such special use permit to furnish such
information to the Zoning Board of Appeals as may be required relevant
to its consideration of the granting of such permit.
(b) Approval; expansion. Approval of any such use shall allow expansion
thereof onto additional land in which the applicant has an interest;
provided, that the applicant specifically requests the Zoning Board of
Appeals to consider such additional land in the granting of a special
exception. Any expansion onto land not so considered by the Zoning
Board of Appeals in the granting of a special exception shall be subject
to additional proceedings before the Zoning Board of Appeals in
accordance with the requirements of this section.
(c) Description of lands; copy of order. The applicant shall submit to the
City Clerk a legal description of all lands considered by the Zoning
Board of Appeals in proceedings pursuant to this section. In the event
the Zoning Board of Appeals approves the proposed use as a special
exception, the Clerk shall, at the expense of the applicant, record a copy
of the order of the Zoning Board of Appeals in the office of the register
of deeds of the county in which such lands are located.

(1) Radioactivity. Any use of radioactive substances, isotopes or
products shall present no hazard to the health, safety or property of
others.
(2) Vibration. Every use shall avoid causing vibration of the land or air
to such an extent as to interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of
any present or prospective legally conforming use of adjoining or
nearby premises.
(3) Noise. Every use shall avoid the emission of noise of such pressure,
loudness, pitch or frequency of occurrence, or any combination
thereof, which would interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of
any present or prospective legally conforming use of adjoining or
nearby premises.
(4) Odor. Every use shall avoid the emission of odorous gases or matter
in such quantities as to be noxious, offensive or injurious beyond
the property line of the parcel devoted to such use or to any present
or prospective legally conforming use.
(5) Heat. Every use shall avoid the discharge or exhausting of heated
air or water in such quantities as to be detrimental to the
reasonable enjoyment of adjoining premises or to plant or animal
life downwind from such discharge.

with natural vegetation.

DIVISION 6
C-3 Central Business District
Sec. 39-125. Intent. [Ord. No. 1333, 5-1-2002115]
The City adopts the regulations set forth in this Division 6 to regulate land
uses in the C-3 Central Business District in order to meet the needs of
the residents of the City of Holland for places of trade, service, assembly,
residence, recreation, and other uses of land; to insure that uses of the
land shall be situated in appropriate locations and relationships; to facilitate
adequate and efficient provision for transportation systems, utility
infrastructure, recreation, and other public service and facility needs; and
to promote public health, safety, and welfare. Regulations adopted herein
facilitate the unique and distinctive mixed use and pedestrian-friendly
environment that define and are necessary for a viable and secure
downtown, provide safety and security for pedestrians, and insure the
appropriate locations and relationships between uses and the public that
differentiate the C-3 Central Business District, by allowing land use and
development relationships that are consistent with the City's "Broadening
the Vision: A Strategic Plan for Downtown Holland".
Sec. 39-126. General. [Ord. No. 1333, 5-1-2002]
(a) Zone district designation. There shall be only one commercial district
designated as the C-3 Central Business District. Only property
contiguous to the C-3 Central Business District or property included
within the area master planned by the City for downtown expansion
may be rezoned to C-3 Central Business District.
(b) Downtown Development Authority. In order to be zoned within the C-3
Central Business District, property must be included within the
boundaries of the Downtown Development Authority as they may from
time to time hereafter be amended.
(c) Street designations. The "A" and "B" streets within the Central Business
District described as follows are shown on maps kept on file in the
offices of the City Clerk, Department of Community Services and
Development, Zoning Administrator, and the Downtown Development
Authority.

(also known as type "A" streets):

and west of each intersection;

Sec. 39-128. Performance requirements. [Ord. No. 1333, 5-1-2002;
3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727]
All development, additions, site alterations, and street-level facade
alterations within the C-3 Central Business District are subject to the
following procedures and performance requirements.
e. Driveways exiting such drive-through facilities are no wider
than 12 feet exiting onto a one-way street and 24 feet exiting
onto a two-way street where the driveway crosses the
sidewalk.
(a) Review process:
(1) Planning Commission review. Where site plan review is otherwise
required, review and approval regarding compliance with
requirements of this section shall be conducted by the Planning
Commission during the site or development plan review process as
described in Article II of this chapter.
(2) Administrative review. All street-level facade alterations and site
alterations not otherwise requiring site plan review shall be
submitted to the Department of Community Services and
Development for review and approval. Review of such proposed
work shall be conducted administratively by the Department of
Community Services and Development. Where staff is required to
make a discretionary determination according to requirements of
this section, notice of the application shall be published in a local
newspaper and shall be given to owners of the property and to
residents and property owners within 300 feet of the subject
property not less than seven nor more than 15 days before the
application will be considered.
At the initiative of the Planning Commission or official responsible
for approving requests, upon the written request of a resident
or property owner within 300 feet made within 15 days of the
mailing of notification, or upon written request of the applicant,
a public hearing shall be held before the Planning Commission
with notification as required above and a decision on whether to
approve the site alteration and/or street-level facade alteration
shall be made by the Planning Commission. A request for a public
hearing shall be filed with the Department of Community Services
and Development. If the applicant or official responsible for
approving the application requests a public hearing, only
notification of the public hearing need be made.
A decision on an application shall not be made unless notification
of the application is given as required by this article. If a public
hearing is not requested or required, a decision on the request
shall be made within 21 days of the receipt of a complete
application. This time may be extended upon mutual agreement of
Sec. 39-127 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-128
C:928
the applicant and the City. If a public hearing is not conducted, and
the application is not approved within the 21 days after receipt, or
within an agreed-upon extension, the application shall be deemed
denied without prejudice.
In this administrative review process, any person aggrieved by the
determination of the Department may appeal the decision within
10 days in writing to the Planning Commission. Such an appeal
shall be filed with the Department of Community Services and
Development. An appeal shall stay all further proceedings, and
shall be heard by the Commission at its next regularly scheduled
meeting, at which time the Commission shall sustain or modify the
determination of the Department. Any appeal of a determination by
the Commission may be taken to a court of competent jurisdiction.
(b) Pedestrian environment. All work shall support and enhance pedestrian
use, character, and safety by satisfying the following criteria, and shall:
(1) Building entrances.
a. All buildings shall have a minimum of one primary entrance
opening to the adjacent sidewalk of the street on which the
building fronts.
b. Where public parking or private parking is available to
patrons, residents, and/or employees to the rear of a building,
whether on the subject property or on a site adjacent to the
subject property, an additional entrance shall be located to
provide access to such parking.
(2) Street level building facades. In order to assure compatibility with
other buildings in the C-3 Central Business District and to promote
a safe and enjoyable walking environment, proposed new
construction of and renovation or alteration to exterior street-level
building facades facing a type "A" street meet the requirements of
Section 39-29. Application of this subsection may be determined by
the Planning Commission to be eligible for the optional plan review
process.
(3) Glazing for visibility and security. Given the nature of pedestrian
activity in the C-3 Central Business District and the desire to
promote a safe pedestrian environment, all glazing at street level
shall be transparent to allow visual contact between individuals
within and outside the building. Reflective glass and
nontransparent glass are not permitted along sidewalks and public
open space areas adjoining street-level facades. Application of this
subsection may be determined by the Planning Commission to be
eligible for the optional plan review process.
(4) Exemption for existing industrial uses. Lawfully nonconforming
industrially used structures, including additions or alterations
Sec. 39-128 CHARTER Sec. 39-128
C:929
thereto, shall not be required to comply with the requirements of
Sections 39-128(b)(2), 39-128(b)(3), or 39-29.
(c) Yard and height requirements. All new construction and expansion of
existing buildings shall comply with the following requirements:
(1) Required front yard.
a. For purposes of this section, all yards of a lot with frontage
along a street shall be considered a front yard.
b. Buildings and structures along a type "A" street shall have a
maximum front yard requirement of six feet.
c. Front yards along type "A" streets may be increased by the
Planning Commission during site plan review where the
Planning Commission determines all of the following
conditions exist. The additional yard area:
1. Provides a special pedestrian-oriented feature such as, but
not limited to, a publicly accessible plaza or garden or
outside dining area which adds amenity to the pedestrian
character of the street;
2. Does not create a significant interruption in the continuity
of street level pedestrian movement and interest;
3. Is compatible and integrated with adjoining properties and
nearby public improvements; and
4. Is not for the purpose of providing parking and/or drivethrough
access between the building and an "A" street.
d. Front yards along a "B" street shall have a maximum front yard
requirement of 25 feet. Application of this subsection may be
determined by the Planning Commission to be eligible for the
optional plan review process.
e. Where lots have frontage on more than one street, the
following shall apply:
1. Buildings and structures located on corner lots shall meet
the yard requirements for each intersecting street.
2. Buildings and structures located on through lots with
frontages along two parallel streets shall satisfy the yard
requirements along only the more restrictive parallel
street (type "A" is more restrictive than type "B").
3. In the case where a site has frontage on more than two
streets, the Planning Commission shall determine which
streets warrant the required yards.

f. For properties north of 6th Street and east of Central Avenue,
buildings containing multiple residential units including
residential uses along the street level shall have the maximum
front yard increase to 12 feet where such additional yard area
is utilized as an entry or porch zone serving the building,
where such yard area is integrated with the public sidewalk
area as a pedestrian area, or where such yard is incorporated
as garden area with the intention of both enhancing the street
level character of the property and providing additional
privacy to street level residential uses.
g. Additions to existing structures. Additions or alterations to
existing structures, conforming in use or otherwise allowable
under this division, that reduce nonconforming yards shall be
permitted without regard to the maximum front yard
requirements of this section. Under this provision, an addition
or alteration to an existing structure, conforming or otherwise
allowable under this division, shall be permitted if it decreases
the side yard, notwithstanding that the addition or alteration
may create front yard space in front of the addition or
alteration that does not comply with the maximum front yard
requirements of Section 39-128(c)(1).
(2) Required side yard. New buildings along type "A" streets shall be
constructed to the side property line. The Planning Commission
may approve a greater setback where the Commission determines
a proposed break in building continuity will be developed as a
publicly accessible park or through-block pedestrian connection;
where such a break in continuity is otherwise permitted and
necessary as driveway access into a site; where the size and
placement of the proposed building cannot readily be changed to
occupy the full site frontage; or where phasing of development on a
site will over time result in a continuous building frontage along the
type "A" street.
(3) Required rear yard. No rear yard is required.
(4) Building height.
a. Commercial and residential buildings exceeding a building
footprint of 800 square feet fronting along a type "A" street
shall be constructed not less than two habitable stories or 26
feet in height, whichever is less. Additions to such buildings
that are proposed further than 50 feet from the type "A" street
shall not be required to meet this minimum height. Application
of this subsection may be determined by the Planning
Commission to be eligible for the optional plan review process.
b. No building or structure shall exceed a maximum of 75 feet in
height except as allowed under Section 39-12.
Sec. 39-128 CHARTER Sec. 39-128
C:931
(d) Vehicular access, parking, service requirements. All new development
and proposed alterations to building sites within the C-3 Central
Business District shall be designed to protect pedestrian safety,
enhance the character of the pedestrian environment, and mitigate
possible negative impacts from such vehicular conditions.
(1) Parking requirements. No off-street parking is required for
nonresidential uses within the C-3 Central Business District. All
nonresidential uses located in the C-3 Central Business District
shall be deemed participants in a community parking program per
Section 39-52 and any applicable City-adopted policies therein, and
shall be exempt from parking requirements of Article IV of this
chapter. Parking for any new residential use shall be provided in
accordance with the requirements set forth in Article IV of this
chapter. Where on-site parking for that residential use is not
available, parking requirements may be met in accordance with the
policies promulgated by the City or its Downtown Development
Authority for the use of its designated downtown public parking
areas for long term and/or overnight parking.
(2) Access to site.
a. Access to parking or off-street loading from a type "A" street is
prohibited except where the Planning Commission determines
all of the following criteria are satisfied:
1. Access is not available from a type "B" street;
2. Driveway width is minimized and such access is
compatible with the manner of access along nearby
portions of the affected street; and
3. Such access does not have a significant negative impact on
pedestrian movement and safety.
b. Application of this subsection may be determined by the
Planning Commission to be eligible for the optional plan review
process.
(3) Placement of parking.
a. Parking shall not be located between a building and street line
of an "A" street. This applies only to that portion of the site
where the frontage of the building is intended to satisfy the "A"
street yard requirements.
b. All parking areas shall be set back at least eight feet from all
street-fronting property lines, with the required setback area
landscaped, or the setback may be reduced to three feet where
the setback area includes a continuous brick wall 30 inches in
height and landscaping between the wall and sidewalk.
Sec. 39-128 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-128
C:932
c. For residential uses, outdoor surface parking shall be set back
from the street line a minimum of 25 feet along type "A" streets
and shall not be accessed directly from any type "A" street
except by a shared driveway where no access is available from
a type "B" street. Only garage doors providing access to
common, shared parking areas are permitted along type "A"
streets. Garage doors and individual driveways serving
garages of individual residences are not permitted facing and
within 25 feet of a type "A" street. Application of this
subsection may be determined by the Planning Commission to
be eligible for the optional plan review process.
d. Parking garages/decks located along type "A" streets shall
integrate permitted nonparking street level uses for at least
the first 25 feet in depth along type "A" street frontages.
Entrances and exits shall be from type "B" streets, wherever
possible. Application of this subsection may be determined by
the Planning Commission to be eligible for the optional plan
review process.
(4) Landscaping and lighting of parking.
a. Design of parking lots shall comply with Sections 39-53 and
39-54.1.
b. Landscaping of the lot interior. In addition to perimeter
landscaping, interior areas of parking lots exceeding 20
parking spaces shall be landscaped with natural vegetation in
the amount of one square foot of landscaping for every 20
square feet of parking area. For purposes of interpretation,
landscaping in this subsection may include trees, shrubs,
ground cover, and grass. For planter islands in parking areas
that include tree wells, surrounding landscaped areas may
include streetscape pavers in place of plant materials.
c. Lighting. Lighting for parking areas shall be in accordance
with the requirements of Section 39-53.
(5) Required off-street loading and unloading space. Provision of
loading shall comply with Section 39-55, provided that,
notwithstanding Section 39-55(b)(2), off-street loading shall not be
located between a building and street line of an "A" street. This
applies only to that portion of the site where the frontage of the
building is intended to satisfy the "A" street yard requirements.
(6) Service area, loading docks, and trash/recycling/dumpster
locations. All service areas, including but not limited to loading
docks, trash dumpsters, recycling containers, and other disposal
areas shall be located and screened to minimize visibility from
publicly accessible areas.

Sec. 39-129. Other required conditions. [Ord. No. 1333, 5-1-2002]
Sec. 39-130. Optional plan review (OPR) for development within the
C-3 Central Business District. [Ord. No. 1333, 5-1-2002; amended
3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727]
(a) All activities within enclosures. All business, servicing or processing
shall be conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building except
for:
(1) Outside display of merchandise for sale on private property,
including but not limited to automobiles, bicycles, and other
objects of transportation, by a tenant or owner of the property; and
(2) Sidewalk cafes pursuant to Chapter 32 of this Code.
(b) Environmental performance standards. All uses in the C-3 Central
Business District shall comply with the environmental guidelines
pertaining to radioactivity, vibration, noise, odor, heat and nuisance as
enumerated in Section 39-74.
(a) Purpose and intent.
(1) Section 39-128 establishes the performance requirements for
design and development of buildings and property in the C-3
Central Business District. The expectation is that these
requirements will be satisfied by every development; however,
circumstances arise which those provisions do not address or did
not foresee. Therefore, this section establishes an alternative
process by which the Planning Commission may evaluate and
approve a development project that does not meet certain
standards of Section 39-128.
(2) It is the intent of the OPR to permit modest flexibility in the
regulation of development projects to achieve successful
integration of a project with the characteristics of the central
business area. The OPR process establishes a mechanism to review
and address special problems or opportunities and unique
proposals or circumstances which cannot otherwise be
accommodated within the standards of the C-3 Central Business
District. Sections 39-29 and 39-128 form the basic framework that
will be used to evaluate an OPR development project, but
specifically identified requirements may be modified by the
Planning Commission in the approval of an application.
(b) Application and procedure. Review under this section of the ordinance
is intended to only occur under unusual circumstances where, during
the course of administrative or Planning Commission review under the
otherwise applicable sections of this division, special circumstances are
identified relating to the property or the proposed development by the
Planning Commission that warrant consideration under the provisions
of the OPR. Prior to the formal submission of an application for a site
Sec. 39-129 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-130
C:934
plan or development plan review of a proposed project within the C-3
that anticipates utilizing the OPR for allowing some variation from
specified requirements, the applicant shall submit a preliminary site
plan for study session review by the Planning Commission. The
Commission will not vote on the request at this time but will provide
reaction and advice regarding the proposed development and the
applicability of ordinance requirements. The applicant may
subsequently submit an application for site or development plan
approval, clearly indicating any sections of the ordinance where OPR
consideration is requested. The application shall be processed in
accordance with the procedural requirements of Section 39-23, with
special note in public notices of any OPR consideration requested.
(c) Review and approval.
(1) In considering an application for plan approval using the OPR
process, the Planning Commission shall not approve such
application unless it determines that:
a. The variation requested is generally consistent with the
intentions of the C-3 Central Business District, and will not
impair the public health, safety, and welfare;
b. The extent of variation from the applicable requirements of
Section 39-128 is modest in the context of the proposed
development and nearby properties;
c. There is public benefit or amenity proposed to be created that
is created and/or enhanced by the variation if permitted;
d. Such use and/or variation from the specific standard will not
result in a violation of Section 39-74 regarding environmental
impact covering radioactivity, vibration, noise, odor, heat, and
nuisance;
e. There is no negative impact presented by those variations on
existing and future development in the area;
f. The variation will not cause substantial detriment to the value
of other property in the area;
g. The variation will not impede the normal and orderly
development and improvement of surrounding property for
uses permitted within the district;
h. Adequate site improvements have been or will be made to
accommodate the proposed variation;
i. The variation will not result in impacts on ingress and egress
that will negatively impact pedestrian or vehicular traffic; and
j. There are circumstances applying to the property or the
proposed development that do not generally apply to other
Sec. 39-130 CHARTER Sec. 39-130
C:935
Sec. 39-130.1. Administrative relief for persons adversely affected
by prohibitions of Section 39-127. [Ord. No. 1333, 5-1-2002; Ord.

properties and development (existing and proposed) in the
same zone district.
(2) The applicant bears the burden of demonstrating that there are
unusual circumstances relating to the property or the proposed
development, that the justification for variation relative to the
issues identified above are sufficient to warrant the flexibility
provided for under this section, and that the proposed variation and

(d) Variations not permissible. A variation shall not be approved where

(1) Allows an intrusion of motor vehicles into a pedestrian

(2) Is solely for the purpose of gaining additional usable space within a
building; or
(3) Is requested only for increased financial return.
(a) Any person aggrieved by the prohibitions of Section 39-127(b) may

provisions of Article XII to hear such application. The applicant shall
have the burden of proving to the Zoning Board of Appeals that:
(1) The proposed use would be essentially a retail commercial use or
service-oriented in nature or a pedestrian-oriented use, as
contrasted with an industrial use, and thereby would be consistent
with the character of the C-3 Central Business District.

be likely to, create or to increase a nuisance.
(b) In reaching a decision on Subsection (a)(2) of this section, the Zoning
Board of Appeals shall apply the environmental guidelines established
in Subsection (a)(1) through (6) of Section 39-74, so as to reasonably
protect all legally conforming uses, present and prospective, of
adjoining and nearby premises. The Zoning Board of Appeals shall also
apply the site plan requirements of this chapter and requirements of
Section 39-128 in order to assure that the proposed use is otherwise
compatible with C-3 Central Business District development.
Sec. 39-130 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-130.1
C:936
DIVISION 6.1
Windmill Island Neighborhood Business District
Sec. 39-131. Intent. [Ord. No. 1213, 6-3-1998]
It is the intent of this district to be consistent with and facilitate the orderly
implementation of the Windmill Island Development Master Plan ("Master
Plan"), as initiated and approved by Holland City Council. The Planning
Commission shall adopt the Master Plan as a component of the 1992 Master
Plan for the physical development of the City, as amended, prior to the
Commission's approval of a development plan. Copies of the Master Plan
document are on file in the offices of the City Clerk, Department of
Community Services and Development, Downtown Development Authority,
and the Windmill Island trust/authority/managing entity.
For purposes of establishing a basis for zoning designation, the Scenario for
Development of the Windmill Island Master Plan, dated June 25, 1997, shall
serve as the City's interim Master Plan for Windmill Island until adoption of
the Master Plan.
The Master Plan and this zone district have as its purposes the realization
of the following objectives for the business, commercial, residential, and
governmental development of Windmill Island:
(a) Windmill Island as a business and commercial district integral with
downtown Holland;
(b) Windmill Island as a new pedestrian-oriented mixed use business
district and neighborhood;
(c) Windmill Island as a place of community culture and history;
(d) Windmill Island as a central place within an environmentally sensitive
region-wide "greenway" open space network;
(e) Windmill Island as a public gathering place for community-wide
celebration of Dutch heritage by residents and visitors alike for
business, commercial, residential, and governmental development; and
(f) Windmill Island as a business, commercial, and residential development
to strengthen the tax base; halt declining property values through
development; and to promote the economic growth and development of
the City.
Sec. 39-131 CHARTER Sec. 39-131
C:937
Sec. 39-132. Establishment, development plan review, procedures.
[Ord. No. 1213, 6-3-1998; amended 3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727]
It is intended that the business, commercial, residential, and
governmental development within this publicly owned and controlled
zone district shall enjoy maximum latitude and flexibility in utilization
of land and facilities, provided consistency is maintained with the
Master Plan. Where inconsistencies exist between the approved
Master Plan and the provisions of Chapters 32 (Streets and Sidewalks)
and 33 (Subdivisions), and the City's requirements for site
condominiums referencing standards and provisions of Chapters 32
and 33, the requirements of the Master Plan shall prevail.
(a) Establishment of zone district. The Windmill Island Neighborhood
Business District is hereby established in accordance with the terms of
this division.
(b) Development plan. The use of any lands within this district shall be
contingent upon the submission and approval of a development plan
and the faithful adherence to that plan. It is anticipated that the
development plan will be part of and consistent with the Master Plan as
approved by the City Council. The development plan approval shall
supersede and be in lieu of any other plan review process of this
chapter.
(c) Development plan approval. The development plan shall be submitted
by the City through the Department of Community Services and
Development for review and approval by the Planning Commission.
(1) Plan review. The development plan shall be reviewed by the
Planning Commission to determine whether the plan conceptually
conflicts with any plans or policies of the City and whether the
development plan meets the goals and objectives of Section
39-131(a) through (f). The primary focus of Commission review
shall be the potential impacts of this development on surrounding
properties and infrastructure.
(2) Submission requirements. In order to consider the development
plan, 17 copies of the following materials shall be submitted at
least 21 days prior to the public hearing:
a. Preliminary development plan indicating property boundaries,
division of land, and proposed general locations for streets,
buildings, and utilities. The development plan shall
differentiate between land which is to be privately used from
that which will remain in public use, and shall specifically
designate land which is to be dedicated for public use as a
public park. The development plan shall also include any
private restrictive covenants proposed to control and restrict
the development of Windmill Island and such additional
Sec. 39-131 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-132
C:938
documentation as the applicant or the Commission shall deem
relevant relating to the review of the development plan.
b. Urban design narrative including:
1. Development framework and design intentions;
2. Preliminary design guidelines for public and private
development, with discussion of such elements of the plan
as:
(i) Pedestrian environment, streetscape, landscape;
(ii) Building location, appearance, performance;
(iii) Vehicular access, parking, service requirements;
(iv) Infrastructure, including utilities, streets, and
drainage; and
(v) Other elements of the plan, including but not limited
to signage, lighting, outdoor dining, outdoor display
and storage, and nuisances;
3. Statement of maximum development density; and
4. Statement of anticipated development schedule and
phasing.
(3) Development plan review procedure.
a. Distribution of plan. The Department of Community Services
and Development shall distribute copies of the development
plan to the Board of Public Works, Department Public Safety,
City Engineer, Department of leisure and cultural services, and
the Department of Community and Neighborhood. The
development plan shall be reviewed and comments developed
with respect to applicable ordinances and policies and to
assure the safe and efficient delivery of community services.
Upon completion of these reviews, the Department of
Community and Neighborhood shall provide copies of the
comments and findings to the City and Planning Commission.
In the event the proposal includes development within the
floodway or floodplain, the proposal shall be reviewed and
comply with requirements of Chapter 6, Article V, Floodplain
Management Provisions, of this Code.
b. Public hearing. Prior to a decision on the development plan,
the Planning Commission shall conduct a public hearing to
solicit comments regarding the proposed plan, subject to
publication of notice and mailing of notice to all properties
within 300 feet of the parcel to be developed.
Sec. 39-132 CHARTER Sec. 39-132
C:939
c. Final approval. A determination of approval of the development
plan shall be deemed final when approved by the Planning
Commission. A report of the Planning Commission findings
shall be submitted to City Council. Upon final approval, an
affidavit shall be recorded with the register of deeds by the
applicant, indicating such approval has been granted.
d. Conditions of approval. The approval of the development plan
may be subject to the establishment of reasonable conditions.
Without limitation on the type of conditions to protect the
health, safety, and welfare, the conditions may include, but not
be limited to, restrictions necessary to:
1. Ensure that public services and facilities affected by the
proposed land use or activity be capable of
accommodating increased service loads caused by the
land use or activity;
2. Protect the natural environment and conserve natural
resources and energy;
3. Ensure compatibility with adjacent uses of land including
the business district of the City;
4. Protect the social and economic well-being of those who
will use the land and residents and owners of adjacent
property;
5. Promote the use of land in a socially and economically
desirable manner; and
6. Be related to the valid exercise of the police power and
purposes which are affected by the proposed activity.
e. Control of plan, modifications, continued compliance.
1. It is the intent that the development plan, approved in
accordance with the foregoing procedures and standards,
shall be the controlling requirement for development in
this district. Upon approval, the development plan shall be
deemed valid in perpetuity, as it may subsequently be
amended as provided below, and all development shall
substantially comply with the approved development plan.
2. While this approval is intended to assure that conceptual
representations made at the time of development plan
approval are adhered to in actual development, it is not
intended to be so rigid as to prohibit adjustments that do
not affect the basic concept of the plan.
(i) Minor modifications to the development plan,
consistent with the Master Plan, may be allowed upon
approval of the City Council or their designated

DIVISION 7.1
C-5 Professional Office Service District
Sec. 39-140. Intent. [Ord. No. 1271, § 1, 2-2-2000]
The C-5 Professional Office Service District is intended to allow for the
development of a variety of office uses of a business, professional, and
institutional nature, as well as to allow for the development of residential
and institutional uses. It is also the intent of this district to locate office
uses in proximity to highways and major arterial streets, and to encourage
office uses as a transitional use and character between adjacent commercial
and residential land uses. The regulations contained in this division are
designed to insure a harmonious relationship between the uses allowed in
this district and abutting land uses.
Sec. 39-141. Permitted uses by right. [Ord. No. 1271, § 1, 2-2-2000;
amended Ord. No. 1732]

Sec. 39-142. Prohibited uses. [Ord. No. 1271, § 1, 2-2-2000]
Within any C-5 District, no building, structure or premises shall be used and
no building or structure shall be erected or altered which is intended or
(a) Corporate, executive, and administrative offices.
(b) Medical and dental clinics for the treatment of humans, professional
office of doctor, dentist, lawyer, accountant, realtor, architect, engineer,
business or financial consultant, cosmetologist, or other similar
professional person.
(c) Churches and other places of religious assembly; public park; public
and private educational uses such as a university, college campus, or
business school; and governmental office buildings.
(d) Banks, credit unions, and other financial institutions, including drivethrough
and outdoor automatic teller facilities.
(e) Residential uses that conform to the use, height, and area requirements
of the nearest residential district located on the same side of the street.
When two or more residential districts are of equal distance, then the
least restrictive district shall apply. Residential dwelling units on the
second floor level or higher of a multifloor mixed-use commercial
building are not required to provide residential yard spaces per the
requirements of said residential district.
(f) Short-term rentals as allowed in Chapter 14 with a certificate of
compliance.
(g) Accessory structures and uses customarily incidental to the permitted
principal uses described above.

DIVISION 8
Sexually Oriented Businesses
Sec. 39-150. Definitions. [Ord. No. 1342, 8-7-2002116; amended
3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727]
For the purpose of this division, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
ADULT ARCADE — An adult arcade means any place to which the public
is permitted or invited wherein coin-operated or slug-operated or
electronically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture machines,
projectors, or other image-producing devices are maintained to show
images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time, and where
the images so displayed are predominantly distinguished or characterized
by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified
anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities".
ADULT BOOKSTORE OR ADULT VIDEO STORE — An adult bookstore or
adult video store means a commercial establishment which has a
substantial portion of its stock-in-trade for sale or rent, for any form of
consideration, any one or more of the following items:
Books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs,
pictures, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, video tapes, any
material in digital format [including, but not limited to compact discs
(CDs) or digital video discs (DVDs)], greeting cards, or video
reproductions, slides, or other visual representations or electronic
media or other merchandise which is predominantly distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of
"specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities"; or
(1)
Instruments, devices, or paraphernalia that are designed for use in
connection with "specified sexual activities".
(2)
116. Editor's Note: This ordinance amended Division 8, adopted by Ord. No. 850, as amended
2-19-1997 by Ord. No. 1188 and 2-3-1999 by Ord. No. 1236, in its entirety.
Sec. 39-150 CHARTER Sec. 39-150
C:951
ADULT CABARET — An adult cabaret means a nightclub, restaurant, or
other similar commercial establishment which regularly features or
displays:
A commercial establishment may have other stock-in-trade which does
not involve the offering for sale or rental of merchandise depicting or
describing "specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities"
and still be categorized as an adult bookstore or adult video store.
Such other stock-in-trade will not serve to exempt such a commercial
establishment from being characterized as an adult bookstore or adult
video store so long as a substantial portion of the commercial
establishment's stock-in-trade is the offering for sale or rental for
consideration the specified merchandise which is predominantly
distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or
description of "specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual
activities".
The phrase "substantial portion of its stock-in-trade" shall be
construed with reference to all relevant factors, including, but not
limited to one or more of the following:
(1) Twenty-five percent or more of the commercial establishment's
gross sales area is used for the sale of merchandise which is
predominantly distinguished or characterized by an emphasis
on the depiction or description of "specified anatomical areas"
or "specified sexual activities". For purposes of this division,
gross sales area is defined as the floor area within the inside
perimeter of the exterior walls of the commercial
establishment, exclusive of vent shafts and courts, storage,
stock, office, and shipping areas, without deduction for
corridors, display fixtures, stairways, public rest rooms, closets,
the thickness of interior walls, columns or other features.
(2) Twenty-five percent or more of the commercial establishment's
stock-in-trade (inventory) is comprised of merchandise which is
predominantly distinguished or characterized by an emphasis
on the depiction or description of "specified anatomical areas"
or "specified sexual activities".
(3) Twenty-five percent or more of the commercial establishment's
gross revenues are generated by the sale or rental of
merchandise which is predominantly distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on the depiction or description of
"specified anatomical areas" or "specified sexual activities".
There is a rebuttable presumption that a commercial establishment
constitutes an adult bookstore or adult video store if the commercial
establishment (1) offers or advertises merchandise that is
predominantly distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on
the depiction or description of "specified anatomical areas" or
"specified sexual activities" and (2) fails to make revenue and stockin-
trade (inventory) or related business records available to the City
upon reasonable advance notice.

ADULT MOTEL — An adult motel means a hotel, motel or similar

ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER — An adult motion-picture theater

Sec. 39-150 CHARTER Sec. 39-150

ESCORT AGENCY — An escort agency means a person or business
association that furnishes, offers to furnish, or advertises to furnish escorts
as one of its primary business purposes for a fee, tip or other consideration.

DIVISION 9
PUD Planned Unit Development District
Sec. 39-165. Findings and intent. [Ord. No. 1585, 5-16-2012117]
There exist in the City properties which are not ideal for traditional
residential, commercial or industrial development. This may be due to
land conditions, topography or as a response to the economic environment
of the City of Holland. It is the purpose and intent of this division to
provide a degree of flexibility for development not attainable in the other
zoning divisions. Promotion of this division will ensure architecturally
complementary design, significant areas of green space with maintained
landscaping, compatible uses within the development and amenities
provided for employers, employees, residents of the area and users of the
facilities provided to the public.
The parcel shall be under the control of one owner or group of owners
and shall be capable of being planned and developed as one integral unit.
Application for a PUD District must be made with the written authorization
of all owners of the site or may be initiated by the City. The designation
of a PUD District requires adherence with the zoning ordinance as well as
the provisions stated herewith including a public hearing for rezoning and
development plan review.
Sec. 39-166. Specifically permitted uses. [Ord. No. 1585, 5-16-2012;
amended 11-28-2012 by Ord. No. 1598; 3-7-2018 by Ord. No. 1727;
Ord. No. 1732]
The following uses, either separately or in conjunction with the delineated
uses, are permitted in a PUD District:
(a) Cooperative, condominium or apartment residences.
(b) Single-family, duplexes, cluster housing, zero-lot-line housing.
(c) Nursing homes, retirement homes, licensed day-care facilities.
(d) All uses permitted by Section 39-210 with required setbacks to be
determined by the Planning Commission.
(e) Executive, professional or administrative offices.
(f) Medical or dental clinics, dispensaries, therapy or treatment centers or
hospitals and those uses typically associated with a hospital.
(g) Radio and television broadcasting stations, excluding towers.
(h) Financial institutions.

Sec. 39-168. Specifically prohibited uses. [Ord. No. 1585,
5-16-2012; amended 11-18-2012 by Ord. No. 1598]
Sec. 39-169. Establishment. [Ord. No. 1585, 5-16-2012]
PUD Districts may be established by initiative of the Planning Commission
and the City Council or may be established by application and approval,
in accordance with procedures of this Code. In either case, the use of any
lands within a PUD District shall be contingent upon the submission and
approval of a development plan and the faithful adherence to that plan. The
development plan approval of a PUD shall supersede and be in lieu of any
other plan review process of this chapter. In the case of an application for
rezoning to a PUD District, the approval of a zone change and the approval
of a development plan shall proceed concurrently. In cases where a PUD
District is existing, a development plan shall be approved by the Planning
Commission prior to issuance of a building permit. Where the scope of a
PUD District indicates development may incorporate several distinct types
of land use, or may span several years, a project plan for the site shall
be presented in its entirety and development plans may be approved in
phases. In the event of a proposed subdivision within a PUD District, the
preliminary plat submitted and approved shall be deemed the subdivision
plan and subsequent development plan review in accordance of this chapter
shall proceed. Except for lot size and area requirements, all applicable
provisions of Chapter 33 shall apply to a subdivision within a PUD District.
In considering approval or disapproval of a plan, the standards set forth in
Section 39-24 shall be applied.
(f) Permitted automotive/vehicular and machinery sales and service uses.
The uses permitted under this section include:
(1) Automobile, truck, recreational vehicles, bus, or other on-road or
off-road vehicles.
(2) Boats or other similar vehicles.
(3) Trailers or other accessory conveyances typically pulled by such
vehicles noted in Subsection (f)(1) and (2) above.
(4) Machinery sales and services.
(a) Mobile home parks.
(b) Automotive and machinery sales and service, except for automotive and
machinery sales and services located south of I-196 and east of and
within 400 feet of the M-40 right-of-way.
(c) Facilities that produce hazards to the public in the form of noxious
odors, excessive radiation, dirt, heat, noise or vibrations which are
perceptible without instrument at the building exterior; or other
potential hazards or nuisances. In applying this criteria, environmental
guidelines of Section 39-74 shall be applicable.
Sec. 39-167 CHARTER Sec. 39-170
C:965
Sec. 39-170. Development plan review. [Ord. No. 1585, 5-16-2012]
All developments in a PUD zone district shall be reviewed in accordance
with Sections 39-20 through 39-27 of this chapter.
Sec. 39-171. Compliance with overlay district requirements. [Ord.
No. 1585, 5-16-2012]
The portions of a property that fall within the boundaries of an overlay
district per Article VIII, Division 5 of this chapter shall comply with the
requirements of the applicable overlay district.
Sec. 39-172. Minimum residential densities. [Ord. No. 1585,
5-16-2012]
Where the lot is served by, or is otherwise available to, a public sewer
system, and when a planned unit development exclusively consists of
residential land uses, there shall be a minimum allowable residential
density of greater than three dwelling units per acre. Where the lot is not
served by, or is not otherwise available to, a public sewer system, and when
a planned unit development exclusively consists of residential land uses,
there shall be a minimum allowable density of greater than two dwelling
units per acre.

ARTICLE VII
Residential District Regulations
DIVISION 1
General Provisions Applicable to Residential Districts
Sec. 39-185. Height and area regulations and exceptions. [Ord. No.
464, § 9-1.12; Ord. No. 975, 3-1-1989; Ord. No. 1188, 2-19-1997;
Ord. No. 1231, 12-16-1998; Ord. No. 1268, 1-19-2000; Ord. No.
1383, 5-12-2004; Ord. No. 1558, 2-2-2011; amended 6-5-2013 by
Ord. No. 1606; 6-3-2015 by Ord. No. 1650; 10-7-2015 by Ord. No.
1656; 6-1-2016 by Ord. No. 1669; Ord. No. 1698; 4-18-2018 by Ord.
No. 1731; 8-1-2018 by Ord. No. 1741]
Height and area regulations shall be specified for each residential district;
provided, however, that the following general exceptions are made:
(a) If 40% or more of all the frontage on one side of a street, between two
intersecting streets, is developed with one- and two-family residences,
the lesser front yard setback so established shall prevail, but nothing in
this division shall be construed to permit any new house closer than five
feet to the front street line. Except where compliance with infill
residential standards of Section 39-198 requires a greater setback, this
section shall not require a front yard greater than that required for the
zone district.
(b) Accessory buildings, except in the PRD Planned Residential
Development District.
(1) No accessory building shall be erected in any required front yard.
(2) Accessory buildings shall be located at least three feet from any
dwelling and at least three feet from any other accessory building
on the lot.
(3) A maximum of two accessory buildings per residential lot less than
two acres in size and a maximum of four accessory buildings per
lots two acres in size or greater shall be permitted.
(4) Accessory buildings shall not exceed 17 feet in average roof height
unless the property is located within an historic district and may be
eligible for additional average roof height per compliance with
Section 39-185(g).
Sec. 39-185 CHARTER Sec. 39-185
C:967
(5) The minimum roof pitch of an accessory building shall be 3/12.
(6) The roof construction shall be such that the use of upper story or
attic space is not usable for any purpose other than light storage.
The bottom chord of the trusses or the ceiling joists shall be
designed for a live load not to exceed 20 pounds per square foot.
This Subsection (b)(6) shall not apply if the upper story is approved
as a second floor ADU.
(c) Accessory buildings in residential districts 50 feet or more from any
street line are permitted two feet from the lot line and, where such use
is contained within or constitutes an integral part of the main building
or is less than 50 feet from any street line, it shall meet all side yard
requirements except as modified in Subsections (d) and (e) of this
section.
(d) In the R-TRN District, accessory buildings and additions to principal
buildings that are located on corner lots and designed for the storage of
vehicles shall have a minimum front yard of 16 feet, except where
vehicle access to an accessory building on a corner lot is from a public
alley, the setback may be reduced to the minimum side yard on a side
street as a condition of a residential infill review.
(e) In the R-TRN District, all new accessory buildings and additions to
principal buildings that are located on corner lots will require a
residential infill review pursuant to Section 39-198.
(f) In the application of these and other residential standards to residential
properties within an historic district, the Zoning Board is hereby
authorized to modify such standards as special exceptions upon public
hearing thereon and a determination from evidence that:
(1) A certificate of appropriateness, conditioned upon zoning approval,
has been issued by the Historic District Commission.
(2) All other requirements of building, fire safety, or other applicable
codes have been met.
Sec. 39-185 HOLLAND CODE Sec. 39-185
C:968
(3) The granting of such exception would not be detrimental to the
health, safety, welfare, or reasonable use and enjoyment of
adjoining or nearby premises.
(g) Accessory dwelling unit.
(1) An accessory dwelling unit (ADU) is a separate, complete
housekeeping unit with kitchen, sleeping area, and full bathroom
facilities, which is a detached from a single-family structure. For
purposes of Section 39-210, a property with a single-family
residence with an ADU permitted by special exception shall be
deemed one single-family use permitted under Section 39-210(a).
(2) All structures designed and used as a temporary or permanent
dwelling detached from a single-family primary residence on a lot
shall be considered an accessory dwelling unit (ADU). ADUs with
not more than two occupants shall be permitted as a special
exception use by the Zoning Board of Appeals.
(3) An attached ADU will be considered as a conversion, and shall fully
comply with the requirements of Section 39-189.
(4) ADUs shall not provide transient accommodations for periods of
less than one month.
(5) Establishment, regulations and conditions. The Zoning Board of
Appeals may grant a special exception to allow for the construction
of a building as an accessory dwelling unit when all of the following
conditions exist:
a. The ADU shall be reviewed and approved pursuant to the
residential infill regulations, Section 39-198, prior to Zoning
Board determination.
b. An applicant seeking permission to establish an accessory
dwelling unit shall submit a site plan of the lot indicating the
location of the accessory dwelling unit and delineating areas
designated for improved off-street parking. Approval by the
Zoning Board shall be conditioned upon strict compliance with
the site plan relating to parking and development.
c. The Zoning Board shall determine the amount and level of
required off-street parking as a condition to the grant of the
special exception, considering the increased use, density, and
safety of vehicular traffic movements on the proposed lot
pursuant to the requirements of Section 39-48.
d. The applicant shall submit a floor plan showing that the ADU
includes a kitchen, bathroom, and sleeping area, and shall
meet all provisions of the Michigan Residential Code and
Chapter 14 of the Holland City Code of Ordinances.
Sec. 39-185 CHARTER Sec. 39-185
C:969
e. The ADU is compatible and harmonious with the established
character of adjoining and nearby residentially developed
lands, and no such ADU shall be approved which would, in the
opinion of the Board, have a detrimental effect on the
reasonable enjoyment of adjoining properties. In making a
determination of compatibility, the Zoning Board shall consider
such factors as:
1. The ADU shall not result in excessive traffic, parking
congestion, or noise.
2. The placement, orientation, and location, of windows and
doors of the ADU will not infringe on the privacy of the
surrounding neighborhood.
3. Adequate landscaping and/or a six-foot-high solid board
fence shall be installed to screen the ADU from the
surrounding neighborhood.
4. No more than two persons shall occupy an ADU.
5. The Zoning Board may approve an ADU subject to such
additional conditions or restrictions as it deems necessary
to assure compatibility with adjoining or nearby
residential property, or to protect the health, safety, and
general welfare.
f. The applicant shall present evidence that the principal
structure on the property is a single-family home.
g. No more than one ADU shall be permitted on a single parcel.
h. Where an ADU is located on a parcel, only one additional
accessory structure shall be allowed except as provided in
Section 39-185(b)(1) for lots exceeding two acres in size.
i. The finding of fact and conclusions of law of the Zoning Board
approving the ADU shall be recorded with the register of deeds
of Ottawa County or Allegan County in which the property is
situated. Any fees incurred for compliance with this section
shall be paid by the applicant.
(6) Development standards.
a. The ADU shall be connected to the City sewer and water
services.
b. An ADU may only be located in a residential zone district.
c. An ADU will not be permitted in the area defined as the Hope
Neighborhood Area.
d. The ADU will have a minimum living space footprint of 120
square feet and a maximum footprint of 720 square feet.

(a) In order to assure a minimum degree of harmony among residential
structures, the following standards shall apply to residential structures
as specified:
(1) No principal structure shall have a habitable floor area of less than
720 square feet. For purposes of this subsection, the term
"habitable" shall include bathrooms, closets, halls and areas of
similar use.
(2) No principal structure shall have a minimum dimension of less than
24 feet along any horizontal elevation of the principal structure.
(3) No principal structure shall be erected which does not include a
pitched roof, having a slope of not less than three inches of rise for
each 12 inches of horizontal dimension, over at least 60% of the
principal structure.
(4) No principal structure shall be erected except upon and
permanently affixed to a solid and continuous foundation of brick,
block, concrete or wood, in accordance with building code
regulations of the City of Holland.
(5) No structure shall be erected or placed which does not comply in
all respects with the building code, the housing code, this chapter
and all other regulations of this Code applicable to the development
and maintenance of residential premises.
(b) For any development which is multiple-family in nature and numbers 12
dwelling units or more in any configuration, the development shall
include a minimum of 50% of the area to be green space. This green
space would be any land area not covered with impervious ground
cover, buildings, roadways, parking installations. The green space shall
be natural vegetation, grass, plantings, pedestrian walkways,
recreational facilities or natural water feature. Stones, wood chips,
walks, sculpture, or similar material or installation may be included as
accessory components of landscaped areas, but shall not in and of
themselves be considered as landscaping. The green space shall be
maintained to provide attractive landscaping and be in compliance with
the provisions of the Charter and Code of the City of Holland.

Sec. 39-188. Premanufactured housing. [Ord. No. 801; Ord. No.
1188, 2-19-1997; Ord. No. 1310, 8-1-2001]
Sec. 39-189. Conversion of buildings and dwellings, except in PRD
Planned Residential Development District. [Ord. No. 464, § 9-1.12;
granting of such special exception shall not be materially detrimental to
the use, enjoyment or value of adjoining premises. In hearing appeals
for special exceptions, the Zoning Board shall consider whether the
specific structure has been designed for a specific site by an architect
or other competent design professional, or incorporates solar heating
or other design innovations which would make strict adherence to the
provisions of Subsection (a) impractical.
(a) Generally. In recognition of improved technology, the need for economic
housing and changing legislative and judicial attitudes toward the
regulation of housing, it is understood that some housing needs may be
met by structures which are constructed in part or in full off-site, and
are transported to a building site for permanent placement.
Premanufactured housing shall be permitted as permanent dwellings in
accordance with the requirements of Section 39-187 and all other
applicable ordinances or statutes. In addition, the exterior of any such
dwelling shall be free of any visible apparatus or equipment relating to
means of transport, including, but not limited to, towing tongues,
undercarriage, wheels, bumpers, lifting hooks or vehicular lighting.
(b) Aesthetic standards. Premanufactured homes shall be constructed and
placed on residential lots in conformance with community aesthetic
standards. The Zoning Board, upon application and public hearing
thereon, shall determine if the proposed mobile home is in conformity
with community aesthetic standards. The Zoning Board shall consider
and prepare findings of fact regarding each of the following criteria:
(1) Whether the type, structure and architectural design of the
proposed mobile home is compatible with the type, structure and
architectural design of reasonably adjacent and contiguous
residential structures;
(2) Whether the exterior appearance, style, roof overhang, window
placement and door arrangement of the proposed mobile home is
compatible with reasonably adjacent and contiguous residential
structures; and
(3) Whether the proposed location of the mobile home and accessory
structures shall be injurious to the health, safety or welfare of the
proposed mobile home or surrounding property.
(c) Exemption. All premanufactured housing that is certified by the State of
Michigan, pursuant to MCLA § 125.1519 Section 19.(1), shall be exempt
from Section 39-188(b).

Sec. 39-192. Home occupations and home businesses. [Ord. No.
1366, § 2, 8-20-2003; Ord. No. 1461, 9-6-2006; Ord. No. 1525,
1-7-2009]
(6) The Zoning Board may approve the conversion of a building or

(d) The findings of fact and conclusions of law of the Zoning Board
